name: Senator HILL
content: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: is it still the view of the Minister that the Khmer Rouge are cooperating in the peace process in Cambodia?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GARETH EVANS
content: —It is the case that the Khmer Rouge have not been especially cooperative in recent times, at least some elements of them, and quite specifically in the Kompong Thom Province where questions do arise about their commitment to the cease-fire agreed last year and about their commitment to the process. Nonetheless, the latest reporting from our mission in Phnom Penh indicates that slow but steady progress is being made in re-establishing the cease-fire and in bringing about a disengagement of the forces.There has been a series of cease-fire violations since February this year. It has involved troops of both the state of Cambodia and the Khmer Rouge. It seems to represent something of a last-ditch effort by both of those factions to extend their territory and influence before the UN troops move in. I do not think it should be seen as any full-scale effort to undermine the settlement. I remain firmly of the view, as I have been from the outset, that the Khmer Rouge lack the capacity to do that in the absence of support, externally, from China, that that support is not now forthcoming and, on the best judgments I and the international community can make, will not be forthcoming in the future.The Chinese Government, on the face of it and from all available evidence, remains wholly committed to the cease-fire process and indeed the whole settlement process. Against that background, it would be very difficult indeed for the Khmer Rouge to seriously undermine that process. Nonetheless, we do not indicate any degree of complacency about the situation. Obviously it is not without risks. We knew that there would be such risks in the whole development of the peace process. We knew there would be difficulties along the way. We are seeing some of those difficulties at the moment, but I do not believe that they are in any way destructive of the peace process; they are just exactly the kinds of things that we might expect at this stage.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator HILL
content: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister also addressed reports of intimidation by the Khmer Rouge within the camps of those who have volunteered to return under the auspices of the United Nations? What degree of bad faith and failure to cooperate in this plan do the Khmer Rouge need to demonstrate to the Minister before the Minister will realise that this is putting the peace process in jeopardy?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GARETH EVANS
content: —There have been some such reports of bad faith on the part of the Khmer Rouge in the camp situation. They are not unexpected, given the track record of the Khmer Rouge over a long period. It does not mean that we are in any way happy about them. Again, to make the judgment that this is somehow putting the whole peace process at risk is fundamentally to misconceive the nature of that process and the dynamics that are at work behind it.Members of the Opposition—and Senator Hill, in particular—have made it their business to misconceive the notion of the peace process all along. Senator Hill has been utterly unable to contemplate with good grace that we might conceivably be doing something that will bring about a lasting peace and lasting justice to the Cambodian community. He has been carping about this in a negative fashion throughout the entire history of this process. He has been doing everything he possibly can to undermine the credibility of that process, to undermine the morale of the people on the ground and to undermine the capacity of the Cambodian people to effectively deal with the problem they are dealing with.Senator Hill was put very comprehensively in his place by Malcolm Fraser over the weekend. He was put even more comprehensively in his place this morning by Ian Harris, the Executive Director of CARE, who made the point on a number of occasions in a radio interview that what Senator Hill and the Opposition are doing is destructive of the peace process, destructive of the situation on the ground and utterly at odds with what needs to happen.There is a very important sense in which we all ought to appreciate and ask ourselves just what the alternatives are to this particular peace process working itself out in the way in which it is laboriously doing it at the moment. The alternatives are simply dreadful. I will leave out all the whacking around the ears Mr Harris gave the Opposition; I will focus simply on one very positive point that he made at the end of his comments this morning, when he said:This is our last chance for peace in Cambodia and unless everyone gives it their best shot then Cambodias just going to disintegrate and were going to have this fermenting sore in Indo-China for goodness knows how many years.He made the point—as I have made the point on innumerable occasions—that the Opposition is just not interested in giving this issue its best shot. I believe—and I think the overwhelming majority of Australians believe—that it should be doing just that. It should stop its carping, stop its misery, stop its grandstanding, stop its political opportunism and stop its attempts to try to build itself some political space on which it can stand and crow `I told you so in the unhappy event that something may go wrong. Of course there are risks associated with this process, but the crucial thing is that we work together to minimise those risks, not talk down a process which is the only chance the Cambodian people have of a lasting peace.

name: Senator BUTTON
content: —I apologise to Senator Newman, but Senator Alston got in first. It should have been a case of ladies first. The fact is that Mr Nasser did make that statement. It is useful to look at the proposals which are there for the car industry. That industry needs a clear policy framework from government. The stability of that framework is crucial to the industrys transition from one which is inward-looking and highly protected to one which is genuinely internationally competitive.In the industry statement of March last year the Government detailed the policy arrangements for this industry through to the year 2000. I notice that immediately after that statement of 12 March last year the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, said:I was, therefore, most pleased to see that the Prime Minister has moved towards—and I emphasise `towards—our tariff decision in Tuesdays statement. I congratulate him on his move in this direction, although he will still have 25 per cent protection in the textile, clothing and footwear industries and 15 per cent protection in the auto industry by the year 2000.It suited Dr Hewson to make that distinction between the Governments tariff policies and the Oppositions tariff policies on 14 March last year. But on 26 March 1992 he said in a press release:The Prime Ministers attempts to portray his tariff policy as distinct from the Coalitions is pure disinformation aimed at the Wills electorate.We should be very careful to take account of Dr Hewsons words of 14 March 1991 which, presumably, he made in a response to the statement of Government policy on this issue.From January next year, the tariff rates for PMVs will be 32.5 per cent, phasing down to 15 per cent in the year 2000. By that time the Governments tariff policy will be 15 per cent for cars, up to 25 per cent for TCF and 5 per cent for general tariffs. That compares with the zero, zero, zero options or negligible, negligible, negligible options of the Opposition.Mr Nasser made the point at the weekend that zero tariffs or very low tariff levels would make it extremely difficult to justify new investments in the Australian automotive industry. Of course, there are reasons for that. The industry is foreign owned and competing for investments with other countries. The size of the market in Australia—it is a volume industry—has to be taken into account in order for the industry to survive, and it has to move to higher levels of exports.

content: —I do not believe that and I have never believed that. In 1984 the Government achieved an historic agreement with the trade unions in this industry that employment in the industry would fall as tariffs came down. We have said that consistently and it has been understood by all sides in the industry policy debate. The important thing about tariff reductions is that we reduce costs to the Australian consumer and, at the same time, put a realistic degree of pressure on the Australian industry to adjust and become more internationally competitive.
Speaker: N/A

content: —Your problem is that you have been too slow with all the other reforms.
Speaker: N/A

content: —Senator Hill says that that is too slow. That sounds funny coming from a member of a government which did nothing throughout the 1970s—in fact, raised tariffs in the 1970s and did nothing about micro-economic reform. In terms of getting a realistic phase-down of protection, many in the coalition are worried about Dr Hewsons change of views in the context of the Wills by-election. For example, last week Senator Boswell said:You cant have Australia completely unprotected, completely working on an open market. A zero tariff policy is just not being realistic.Senator Boswell said that in relation to primary industries, essentially. The point is that the coalition cannot have it two ways: it cannot have zero levels of protection for manufacturing industry and higher levels of protection for primary industry in the same coalition policy. I would have thought there would be grave difficulty in doing that. Senator Boswell, who went on to say that he had had regular exchanges of views with Dr Hewson about this issue, confirmed his view on the radio at the weekend.The fact of the matter is that the Government has a stable reduction policy for tariffs and protection; it has been successful in helping internationalise the Australian motor vehicle industry. The industry which never exported anything when those opposite were in government is now exporting $1.2 billion worth of components and vehicles, and will continue to increase that performance as it internationalises and becomes more globally competitive. That can only be done in a regime which is sensible and which provides for a practical transition from high protection, which those opposite imposed on it, to low protection, which we are seeking.

name: Senator DURACK
content: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It follows the answer he gave to my colleague Senator Hill a short time ago. I ask the Minister: has he seen reported comments in the Weekend Australian by the commander of the Cambodian peacekeeping forces, General Sanderson, who said that under the terms of the Paris peace agreements last October peacekeeping forces cannot be sent into a `hot war situation but only monitor and verify a cease-fire? Does the Minister agree with this statement by General Sanderson? In the light of the current increased tempo of fighting in Cambodia, which the Minister has acknowledged is occurring, what impact does that have on the timetable for the deployment of the main Australian peacekeeping force?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GARETH EVANS
content: —I have seen the reported comments of General Sanderson and I do agree with them. It is the case that under the UN peace plan, the role of the UN forces, the military forces, is not that of peace enforcement in the sense of actively intervening to stop a conflict presently being waged. It is rather the role of peacekeeping, which is to monitor, verify and supervise a peace settlement already in existence and an associated cease-fire.The difficulty is that we are in a transitional situation where the cease-fire has been agreed to but violations are occurring; that is not unknown in these situations. The judgment that General Sanderson and the UNTAC forces generally have to make is how they handle themselves on the ground in response to that. What General Sanderson is reported as saying is that he would be looking for the factions to agree to proposals for the separation of forces in those areas. He said:If that eventuates . . . Ive told them Ill be prepared to put UN troops in there. . . . I cant put troops in there until its clear where everyone is and what they are prepared to do.That is an exact statement of the situation. Under those circumstances, one would not expect Australian troops or any other UNTAC troops to be put at risk of involvement in a separation exercise. That is not what they are there for. They are there to monitor, supervise and verify a settlement, once reached, and a cease-fire that is in existence. What we all have to try to do is ensure that the cease-fire is honoured and observed.As I said in response to the earlier question, I do not believe that there is any evidence for claiming that the situation is in any way out of control in this respect or that the settlement process is, in some fundamental way, at risk. There are always going to be risks associated with this process. We know very well the risks associated with mines and disease. There are also the associated risks of troops being caught up in cross-fire that might develop out of a clear blue sky or in the kind of situation in which Colonel Stuart unhappily found himself with random fire at his helicopter in a situation where he was just simply scrutinising and seeking to establish the basis for a later involvement of troops on the ground. This is exactly the sort of situation that could have been anticipated, given everything we know about the problems over a long time in Cambodia. Again, I ask that the Opposition contribute in a constructive and bipartisan way to this whole enterprise rather than carping, criticising and trying to talk the situation down.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator DURACK
content: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the answer that Senator Evans has just given, I refer to the part of my question which he did not answer: what effect have the events which he has just described had on the timetable for the deployment of the main Australian force? Has there been any effect?

content: —It is quite premature to make any judgment about that. The troops will be deployed in the first instance—infantry, communicators, which is the role that Australia is playing, and logistic support troops—as possible into Phnom Penh, into the initial catchment area. When they will be deployed in the other regions of the country, in particular those where there is some doubt about whether the cease-fire is holding, will be a matter for the judgment of the force commander.What is happening at the moment certainly will not influence the basic pattern of deployment of troops from Australia or anywhere else into the country pursuant to the basic peace plan. To do so would be to unhappily lose a lot of the momentum that is at last now being generated. We believe that there are plenty of grounds for optimism that this will result in an effective transitional process.

The Western Australian Government, through its port operations task force—

name: Senator REYNOLDS
content: —I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What progress has been made in responding to the recommendations of the national inquiry into racial violence? Has racism been included on the agenda of the next meeting of Commonwealth-State Attorneys-General?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator TATE
content: —The Government did table its response to the recommendations of the national inquiry into racist violence. I think it was in mid-December last year that the Attorney-General put down a statement in the House of Representatives. Earlier this year he wrote to his counterparts in the States drawing their attention to that response and seeking their active support in implementing the measures that need to be taken to ensure that Australia does not have those features of a racist society, or tolerate within it expressions of racism by individuals or by groups.I believe that a joint ministerial forum is scheduled to take up these matters. Also, this can be linked to the necessary response by all governments to the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Both reports note those measures which need to be taken, particularly in changing the culture. The report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody contains measures in relation to the police force and the court officers who find themselves at the front line of dealing with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That is not to say that those particular groups—the police and the court officers—are more racist than any other part of the Australian community. It is just that, quite clearly, they have more occasion to come into contact with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. There are so many occasions on which, rather than these people being able to be diverted away from those particular processes—as is recommended by the Royal Commission—they come into contact with the law enforcement agencies in a particularly harsh way at times.I understand that the Minister, Mr Tickner, held a meeting with his counterparts last Friday in Melbourne. It is quite clear that there is still a way to go to ensure that the States assume their responsibilities in regard to meeting the recommendations of that particular Commission. However, the Australian Police Commissioners Council has taken a joint approach to improving the training of police. There will be cross-cultural training programs. In particular, I am very confident that the selection of trainees now being undertaken in the various police forces is being done in such a way that initially they will be capable of benefiting from training which will ensure that in their contact with members of the community and minority groups they will demonstrate the sensitivity which, perhaps, has not been required of them by the Australian community hitherto.I am sure that, as those meetings are held over the next few weeks and as the response by the Commonwealth Government to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody is made tomorrow, Senator Reynolds will become more aware of the sorts of programs being undertaken to ensure that racism is not a feature of the Australian community.

name: Senator CHAPMAN
content: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of the massive 436 per cent blow-out in the cost of funding the Yes case for union amalgamations—from an estimate of $750,000 in 1988 to over $4m by the end of this financial year? What is the cause of this blow-out? How much more money will the Government spend on funding what are, in many cases, wealthy unions to assist in amalgamations? Can the Minister explain to the Parliament and to the Australian people why $4m of their tax dollars is being spent to fund the Yes case for union amalgamations in breach of International Labour Organisation protocol?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator COOK
content: —The weird thing about this question is that all of the estimates for our labour market reform program have been through the scrutiny, in successive Budgets, of the Estimates committees and the Committee of the Whole, and approved. On the advice before me, the allegation of a blow-out is not justified at all. We are within program expenditure.We have here a series of allegations. It should be said that our union rationalisation program is part of an overall program for labour market adjustment which this Government is running. If one looks at the expenditure in the budgetary years 1990-91 and 1991-92, we have spent a total of $18.9m in the labour market adjustment program. Of that $18.9m, $11.2m has gone to employer organisations or employers; $5.8m has gone to trade unions; and $1.9m has gone to joint bids by employers and trade unions acting together. As a consequence of that, almost twice as much as has gone to trade unions has gone to individual employers and employer organisations.The labour market adjustment program is the reason there is now a revolution in the Australian workplace. It is the reason we have seen a low level of industrial disputes, success in award restructuring, the reform of workplace and managerial practices, and a change from the previous climate of conflict to a climate of cooperation in the Australian workplace.The union rationalisation program is based on unions deciding to amalgamate, consistent with our objective of reducing the number of trade unions in Australia. That is an objective supported by the Jackson report into manufacturing industry in 1975, the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1976, the Myers report on technological change in 1980, the Hancock report in 1985, the Pappas Carter report in 1990 and Business Council of Australia surveys.All of those reports to government, not only our Government but previous governments as well, have supported the need to reduce the number of trade unions in Australia. That program has supported that objective. It has increased the flexibility in the workplace for employers. It has meant that career-pathing has been able to be introduced. It is a pre-condition for effective workplace bargaining and it has an absolutely dramatic effect on reducing the number of demarcation disputes where there is more than one union claiming the right to work in a particular workplace. It underpins our 1990 legislation and it is for the particular costs where unions, as independent organisations, have decided of their own volition, without direction from this Government, that they wish to amalgamate. We then support that decision by information and educational programs and the defrayment of some of the excessive legal costs that have been hitherto involved in the proposal.The last part of this very silly question, I must say, goes to an allegation that, in doing this, we are somehow contravening ILO conventions. I might say I am very pleased that the Opposition has discovered ILO conventions because I expect it will hear more about them from the Government as the course of our term continues. The only basis for that allegation could have been a report in the Herald-Sun today. Someone once said, `Never believe everything you read in a newspaper. Whoever said it must have had the Herald-Sun in mind. I now table the document which is the source document upon which the Herald-Sun appears to have based that allegation. I will quote from the last paragraph of this document.

content: —Senator Zakharov raises in a timely way the question of the way in which the Australian community ought to deal with the problem of unsafe products in the marketplace. Indeed, it is that particular directive which will be adopted in Australia, and also by our trading partners in north Asia, as the model for product liability legislation. I hope that that legislation will be passed during the course of the autumn sittings.It is one thing to have legislation in place, and even acknowledge in a spasmodic or anecdotal way the various injuries and loss to property that occur as a result of defective products, but it is another thing to have a comprehensive, Australia-wide view of what is going on. I believe that The Investigators did a great service to the Australian community by pointing out that there is a very real need to have a coordinated Australia-wide register of accidents as they occur as a result of defective products in the marketplace. We are moving in that direction in a reasonably satisfactory way, although certainly more is required to be done.The consumer affairs agencies do coordinate well but, as the coroner in the Mistral fan tragedy pointed out, some agencies—such as electricity authorities which test electrical products and become aware of deficiencies in certain electrical products—have not been so forthcoming in passing on that information to consumer affairs authorities. There has been something of a gap and such a gap can have tragic consequences if the Australian community is not alerted to dangerous electrical faults that can occur in some products.In addition, the casualty sections of Australias major hospitals have been involved—and this has been organised by the Australian Institute of Health—in putting together a surveillance of major injuries presenting at their casualty departments and accident units. This is already proving to be very helpful. Some 22 hospitals are involved in this program Australia-wide, including the Royal Childrens Hospital in Melbourne, Camperdown in Sydney, Westmead in Sydney, the Mater Adults and Childrens Hospitals in Queensland, and so on. Through the experience of these casualty wards, we are receiving very good data on various injuries.Recently it has emerged that exercise bikes are a cause of young children attending these casualty departments; not from falling off the bicycles or anything like that, but simply because they have caught their fingers in the spokes or the chains of these exercise bikes. This is a very real indication of the need to have mandatory standards imposed on such products. The same data has been presented concerning childrens cots and this is also extremely important.An Australia-wide process is in place to make people aware of the injuries caused by defective products. This process will be complemented by a new legal regime which will well satisfy the Australian community when it is finally in place.

name: Senator SPINDLER
content: —The reason I have put forward this particular matter of public importance—the failure of the Keating One Nation statement to provide for adequate action to reduce unemployment—is the total disregard that the Government has displayed towards the magnitude of the crisis that one million unemployed people in Australia represents. Not only has the Government disregarded the magnitude of the crisis but it has also disregarded the social consequences that will arise from such an extraordinary number of people being out of work. Yet, in his One Nation statement, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) provided a total of only $2.3 billion public expenditure, despite the generally acknowledged principle that increased public expenditure is one of the quickest ways to increase jobs, to increase work opportunities. All $2.3 billion will achieve is 35,000 jobs; and this is in the face of one million jobless.Another emergency measure which would show quick results, a pause in tariff cuts, was rejected very clearly, very quickly and almost joyously by the Prime Minister in his statement. Indeed, this has been the position of the Government from the word go. The Government has always maintained that we must reduce tariffs. It has put forward a program to reduce those tariffs and it has made it very clear that it is not going to depart from that program of tariff reductions, no matter what the consequences.I am a little at a loss to work out how a number of media commentators, or should I perhaps say subeditors, were able to say last week that the Prime Minister had performed a back flip. He had done nothing of the sort. When we read the statements that the Prime Minister has put down and the statements that other Ministers have confirmed, it is quite clear that this Government is intent on continuing its program of tariff cuts, no matter what it does to our manufacturing industries. It is destroying what is left of the Australian manufacturing base.It is no consolation that the Prime Minister was right when he said that the Liberal Party would do worse. Its policy is a scorched earth policy. It would have no pump-priming. It would have substantial spending cuts in community services and tighter monetary policies.The magnitude of the problem can hardly be overstated. Between January 1990 and January 1992, unemployment almost doubled from 550,400 to 960,000—that is, almost one million people. In fact, unemployment is almost certain to be above even that figure because many people have given up looking for jobs. But perhaps it is worse when we consider how long people have been out of work. The number of people who have been out of work for one year or more almost trebled in the same period, from 115,900 to 274,200.I can do no better than to quote Mr John Phillips, deputy governor of the Reserve Bank, who, in turn, was been quoted by Tim Colebatch in his excellent article in the Age of 20 March 1992:I believe that the rising level of structural, or underlying, unemployment is the most worrying long-term problem facing government in Australia. . . Low inflation will be a necessary, though not sufficient, precondition for dealing with that problem. Many areas of policy are involved and some further lateral thinking may also be needed.When I read some time ago that youth unemployment had reached 30 per cent in many areas, I was reminded of another statistic. When Hitler succeeded in his bid for power in Germany in the early 1930s, some 30 per cent of German youth between the ages of 18 and 25 had never had a job. I am not suggesting that we are on the brink of a fascist society, but we might note that last year there was an increase of 10 per cent in our prison population, and we might also note that we are now in a much worse position. We now have in the north-west region of Melbourne—and Wills is located in that region—50.6 per cent youth unemployment; more than half of the young people in that region in Wills are out of a job. The overall jobless rate in that region is 19 per cent.Take away peoples self-sufficiency and one takes away their self-esteem, their purpose in life and their future. One replaces them with political extremes, racism, increased crime rates, family breakdown and domestic violence—and this will be so whether we become a republic or remain a constitutional monarchy. It is in this context that we must view the Prime Ministers One Nation statement and the Hewson tax package with its callous disregard for people without work.It is also in this context that the Senate needs to consider the Prime Ministers point-blank refusal, as I have outlined before, to stop further cuts in tariffs, cuts which will continue to destroy what is left of Australias manufacturing industry, much of which is concentrated in Victoria. Much of it—and it is perhaps ironic that this is where we are to have the by-election—is concentrated in the electorate of Wills where a very high proportion of industry is in textiles, clothing and footwear.Last year, 18 factories closed in the Wills electorate. Six hundred jobs were lost, and a further 2,000 jobs are at risk. However, the problem is greater. A statement by the TCF Council released on 30 January 1992 states:-total TCF gross product has fallen by 7% and 12% respectively over the last two years.That is a total of 19 per cent. The statement continues:-official figures show that total TCF employment has fallen by 5% in the last two years and in the more vulnerable, labour intensive clothing and footwear sector employment has declined by 15%.-however, the official data understates the full impact of the decline with an estimated 40% of the industry operating shorter than normal work time (eg. 3 or 4 day weeks, limited overtime, etc).In one sense, the TCF Council, in its statement on 27 February, welcomes the Governments $51m provided in the Prime Ministers statement, but it also says that although this will be of help to restructure the economy in the long term, it will do nothing to provide jobs for those people who need them right now.The pause in tariff reductions is not the only measure missing in the Keating package. The tax on employment—payroll tax—remains; superannuation funds are free to invest overseas to create jobs off-shore; and there is to be no further reduction in the interest rate. Clearly, we cannot depend just on our domestic market. To revive our economy and generate jobs, we must boost our export performance and cut imports. Here Mr Keating offers an increase in Austrade activities, some marginal improvement in export finance arrangements and the Australian Technology Group to develop Australian inventions. Does he really think that a one-off capital base of $30m will be enough? Does it go anywhere near enough to gearing up our industry in Australia?Other nations are not afraid to protect their jobs. The United States uses protective tariffs for a large range of industrial products, including ball-bearings and computers, and its subsidies for primary products are legendary. In 1990, primary producers in the United States and the European Community countries were paid subsidies equal to 44 per cent of farm output. Both the United States and the European Community have made it clear that they are unlikely to accept Mr Dunkels GATT proposals to reduce their farm subsidies. Even if they did, it would be only a partial phase-out over several years.We need to take decisive action to reduce imports. We must place a 10 per cent tariff on luxury goods, more extensive import quotas, tougher and faster anti-dumping procedures and expansion of the export credit used in the car industry plan to tie imports to the level of exports. Dumping measures require particular attention. We now have a process that lasts almost a year and which burdens people who are being ruined by cheap imports with the substantial cost of providing evidence, not only that they are being hurt, but also that the dumping of cheap products is what actually does the damage. The onus should be placed on the importer to show that a product at a cost below the price on the domestic market is not being dumped in Australia. Clearly, the evidence that this is harming the Australian industry will be there for all to see. It can be seen in the figures I have quoted today which were provided by the TCF Council and other industry sectors.To boost exports, we need a pause in tariff cuts, as previously stated; but, even more importantly, we need targeted measures to assist specific industry sectors with export potential. The accelerated depreciation provisions should have been targeted in this way, as should funding for research and development. The CSIRO missed out totally in Mr Keatings statement, and tax deductibility for research and development will be reduced from 150 per cent to 125 per cent, while our national expenditure continues at less than half of what is spent by other nations such as Japan, Germany and the United States.Our neglect shows. Last year our manufactured exports increased by 56 per cent—in itself a pleasing figure, but not when one compares it with 91.9 per cent for Japan, 82.8 per cent for the United States, and 140.4 per cent for Germany. Australia will not be able to provide jobs for its citizens within a sustainable economy framework unless it can compete in international markets. We will not be able to do so unless we first put an end to further job losses and preserve what is left of our manufacturing base, and then proceed to build up our capacity in selected industry sectors—in other words, where investment and incentives will provide real returns. The second strand is to unlock new markets for our primary products and to challenge the restrictive barriers and subsidies now in place. To achieve these goals, our Government has to stop relying on so-called free markets manipulated by others and instead provide economic leadership on a goal-directed and targeted basis.On the evidence before us so far, one would have to say that the outlook for a change in government policy is unlikely. One would have to say that the alternative would be worse. So what is the future that we are facing? Once again, the electorate of Wills provides an instructive lesson. It is now well and truly on the public record that the Australian Democrats are running there on a policy of interventionist economic strategies—on tariffs, but also on targeted assistance to industry. It is also clear that the Independent candidate, Mr Cleary, is running on a similar policy. In fact, he has exchanged preferences with the Australian Democrats precisely on that basis: that we need a change in economic direction if we are not to go down the drain.This exchange of preferences is not the beginning; it is the continuation of a process that started some time ago. As long ago as the middle of last year, a number of organisations—the Australian Democrats, several unions, the Rainbow Alliance, some Green groups, the New Left Party—got together on the basis that something must be done, that an alternative must be developed, that we cannot continue this disastrous slide on which the Government has put us and down which the Opposition would push us even further.It might be instructive if I quote from a statement that was released in Melbourne in December 1991. The statement says—and all these organisations, including the unions, have agreed to it—that the urgent measures that we require to get our economy up and running again, to provide jobs and to stop the social destruction that we are facing are as follows:1. Substantial increases in public sector expenditure at State and Commonwealth level2. Selective incentives to assist key industry sectors with potential for import replacement and for exports3. Extensive measures aimed at a substantial reduction of imports, including tariffs, quotas, quality controls, effective anti-dumping measures, tax incentives and penalties4. Measures to boost savings and domestic capital, including tax incentives for savings placed in a Development Fund and requirements on Superannuation Funds to invest in Australian public utilities and other socially desirable projects5. Substantially increased expenditure on research, education and training.And so it goes on. It is important to draw parallels with New Zealand, where an alternative alliance has obtained figures between 30 per cent and 40 per cent, and with Canada, where a similar alliance, which rejects the slavish adherence to free markets, has achieved similar results.It is for this reason that the by-election in Wills will be a milestone in Australian political history and in the way in which we run our economy. It is perfectly clear that we cannot continue to operate, to function, in the way in which we have. The results are there—one million unemployed, the break-up of families, increased crime rates, a generation growing up with no sense of a future.In closing, I quote from a resolution passed by the ATEA at an extraordinary meeting, in part as a contribution to the common process that these organisations are pursuing. The resolution reads as follows:To aim to build support for Independent Politicians and/or candidates from the Australian Democrats with the specific aim of building a parliamentary force which will form a barrier against and opposition to the right wing legislation and actions of governments thrown up by the two major political parties.

name: Senator TATE

content: —I rise to refute the allegation contained in the matter of public importance moved by the Australian Democrats this afternoon, namely:The failure of the Keating One Nation statement to provide for adequate action to reduce unemployment.What was totally lacking from the contribution by Senator Spindler, of course, was an indication of an understanding of the complexity of the task facing Australia. I do not doubt that there were some motives of a humanitarian kind in his contribution. But the question of unemployment will not be solved by preserving the tariff walls, for example, which have created a situation where Australian industry has been unable to be so modernised and transformed that it can sell products on the world market, which the world market wishes to purchase and, in purchasing, sustains Australians in employment in those industries.This problem of unemployment will certainly not be solved by a Democrats Cabinet—God forbid—sitting in isolation in Canberra, pandering to groups as they emerge during particular political campaigns, and deciding which industries should be targeted in order to receive government largesse. It would be even worse if the Democrats, instead of trustees of superannuation funds, were to decide where to direct the savings of Australians, which are so incredibly important not only for this nation, but also, speaking individually, for the future retirement incomes of so many of those Australians. To replace trustees, who are under a fiduciary duty to use those funds in a way which aids those who have made contributions to superannuation, with the Democrats deciding that it should go into this industry or that industry or here rather than there, is totally unacceptable.Senator Spindler tried to portray the matter as if one should seek to avoid extremes. On the tariff question, the Democrats are somewhat caught out because it is quite clear where the extremes lie in this debate. I have already mentioned Senator Spindlers extreme, that of wishing to preserve the tariff walls. One then has the extreme of the Opposition parties—or at least the Liberal Party leading the National Party in this regard—wishing to go to zero tariffs by the year 2000.But our approach is a middle one—a phased approach, which therefore has that humane touch, which I know Senator Spindler is seeking, and which moderates the very dry economics which would say that one has to move across the whole range of Australian industry to zero tariffs by the year 2000. Senator Spindler would know that in relation to the very industries he mentioned, such as the textiles, clothing and footwear and motor vehicle industries, that is not our objective. There will be a phasing out but not a complete abolition of tariffs in that regard.

That will help sustain and increase employment in those retail sectors which have been extremely hard hit, as we know.That is an example of saying to the households of Australia, the families of Australia, that it is not for governments, it is not for the Democrats, to decide where money should be put in order to boost employment. That is not the sole way to go. A very good way to go is to say to Australian families, `We will put this one-off Easter bonus in your hands. content: —Senator Powell mentioned the GST. I think it is very timely that she has raised that in the course of this debate; I was not going to. But since she has, it is well worth noting that it is claimed in the Fightback statement of the Opposition, led by Dr Hewson, and in the propaganda that over the last week has gone into every postbox and every household around Australia, that under the Fightback package some two million jobs will be created over a period. In all the documentation that surrounds that Fightback package, one finds one very interesting fact: there is no mention of the GST in respect of the two million jobs that are sought to be portrayed as being able to be created as a result of implementing this package. It is not in the model and it does not figure in the calculation that led to that figure of two million jobs.Senator Powell might say, `Senator Tate, why should we take your line on this?. I might mention Gerard Henderson, who is certainly not an ideological bedfellow of the Australian Labor Party. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 December last year he said:For Hewson and company this is just as well. Fightback! makes it clear that the promise of 2 million soundly based jobs and an unemployment level of 5.2 per cent by the year 2000 is based on Scenario C.He goes on to analyse scenario C and comes to this conclusion:In other words, the firm warranty that some 2 million jobs will be created and unemployment halved by the end of the century is just a guess. Well meaning, no doubt. Yet a hypothesis just the same. What is more, the AEM model on which this overtly optimistic promise is based does not take into account the inflationary impact of the Coalitions across-the-board goods and services tax (GST). It is all pie in the sky.So what we have had, unfortunately, placed in every letterbox throughout Australia over the last week is a hoax—nothing less than a hoax on the Australian people. The two million job figure has no relationship whatsoever to the inflationary impact of the goods and services tax on the Australian economy and our whole social life, whether one is talking about the tourism sector, which is a matter of great interest to my friend and Tasmanian colleague, Senator Nick Sherry—

name: Senator MICHAEL BAUME
content: —The coalition supports the terms of the following matter of public importance proposed by the Australian Democrats:The failure of the Keating One Nation statement to provide for adequate action to reduce unemployment.But it rejects, of course, their quaint witchdoctor-like responses and the manner in which they feel that this vital matter, this matter of internal sickness in the Australian economy, can be fixed. There are no bandaid solutions possible. There are no solutions possible which simply involve throwing money at the problem and hoping some of it sticks.The key thing behind this matter of public importance is that the man who created the crisis—the man who misled the Australian people about how everything was on track and that there would be no recession; this man who deliberately distorted figures to make them appear to be a wonderful set of numbers; this man who dragged Australia unnecessarily into this disastrous recession—now claims some sort of right to lead us out of the disaster he himself created. The man did not know what he was creating—or if he did know what he was creating, his sin is even worse—and he certainly does not know how to get us out of it.The Government is once again simply trying to buy its way out of trouble and back into government with other peoples money. Some of that money that is being thrown around in the One Nation package is to be borrowed from foreigners again. We have already seen how much this Government has forced Australia into debt by creating the jobs it created for a while during its recovery program from the previous recession. We have seen the enormous cost to Australias foreign debt involved in this Governments crazy proposals which inevitably failed in the long run. Not only is it going to borrow more from overseas to do it, it is going to rip some more off taxpayers. If we compare that with the 30 per cent across-the-board tax cuts under Fightback, we will see that there is an enormous difference between the way the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party want to cure this cancer that is in our economy and the way we want to really fix it once and for all.When we listen to Senator Tate, we find it funny how Labor members magically omit from every discussion about the Fightback package anything that is clearly of huge benefit. All we hear is doom, gloom and disaster. Senator Tate is apparently unaware of the fact that under Fightback there will a 30 per cent across-the-board cut in income taxes. I cannot believe that Senator Tate would be so unscrupulous as deliberately to ignore that when he makes an analysis of Fightback. He must have just forgotten it because he certainly did not mention it. What sort of integrity is that when dealing with a subject as vital as the recovery of the Australian economy from this disaster brought about by one man—Paul Keating?It seems to me incredible that a man of Senator Tates standing would come into this place and say that the only thing the coalition is going to do is introduce a goods and services tax which will be inflationary, when he knows that not to be so. He knows that the goods and services tax will have a minute impact on inflation which will not be continuing. In fact, there will be no need to compensate workers for the higher costs of GST because they will get a huge tax cut. That is exactly the same technique that this Government has used of offsetting increases in costs of living with tax cuts instead of higher wages. It is a principle the Labor Party accepts when it chooses to do so but not, of course, at the moment.Let us recognise this: the real measure of compassion is how we fix the basic problems that are affecting those people in need. This Government does nothing to fix the basic problems. Once again, it is handing out bandaids funded by the taxpayer and overseas borrowings.The Democrats say that the $2.3 billion which the Labor Party sets out in its One Nation package is not enough in job creation. But without structural change, without that money being funded, the One Nation package is a guarantee of continuing disaster. It provides absolutely no hope for Australia, whereas the Oppositions Fightback package is full of genuine structural reform aimed at rebuilding Australia. There is nothing in the Governments program, except for some unfunded capital works, which will basically and structurally correct the cancer eating away at Australias economic health. It is that cancer which is creating this terrible level of unemployment.The raw figures, the unadjusted figures, for February show that just under one million Australians are unable to find jobs. I am glad that the Democrats have at last recognised the merit of the figures I have been presenting here and which the Government continually pretends are unreasonable. The figures are from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I am glad that the Democrats now accept those figures as factual, because they are.For example, the number of full time jobs in Australia lost over the last two years of this recession is 300,000—300,000 jobs wiped out. Of those jobs, 62 cent are for young Australians aged 15 to 19. The young people of Australia are carrying the major burden of this Governments disgraceful and dishonourable policies, yet we see Ministers in this Government pretending that there is really no problem for young Australians and that the real unemployment rate for young Australians is 8.8 per cent. They can see the number of jobs wiped out for young Australians. Almost two-thirds of the full time jobs wiped out over the last two years have been for young people aged 15 to 19.We have had an increase in the total unemployment of Australians by 404,000—that is a 68 per cent increase in the number of people out of work in two years. It is not just a little increase, not just a modest one, not just an adjustment—it is a massive increase of two-thirds in the people who are now out of work. That is despite a huge rise of 137,000 people having to put up with part time jobs. name: Senator MICHAEL BAUME
content: —For youth—that is, people aged 15 to 19—40 per cent of all the full time jobs that existed two years ago have been wiped out in Australia. Two out of every five full time jobs held by young people in Australia have been wiped out. That means the loss of 183,000 jobs. Despite that loss of 183,000 jobs, there has been an increase of only something like 63,000 in the number of 15- to 19-year-olds who are listed as unemployed. In other words, more than 100,000 young people appear to have disappeared from the figures. This indicates that there is a massive level of hidden unemployment on top of these disastrous figures. As my Leader, John Hewson, said in the House of Representatives, behind these figures there are other disastrous realities. He said:There are 262,000 families in which the chief breadwinner is unemployed, which is up 40 per cent in just the last year. There are 218,000 Australian children living in a family in which no-one has a job, which is up 40 per cent in the last year. There are 248,000 Australians that have been unemployed for more than a year, which is an 88 per cent increase in just the last 12 months. There are 500,000 children living in poverty—we were told by the former Prime Minister, of course, that no child would be living in poverty in Australia—and 75,000 homeless—and an extra 140,000 families a year have been plunged into extended poverty because of this recession.Youth unemployment in Australia is around 30 per cent, but in some of the regional areas outside Sydney and Melbourne it is as high as 40 or 50 per cent.It is certainly around that level in my area of Wollongong. Dr Hewson continued:There are 60,000 young Australians who could not get into university this year and nearly 100,000 young Australians who could not get into TAFE or technical colleges.This is the legacy of Mr Keating, the man who promised that there would be no recession and then gave us the recession we had to have; the man who said that it was an engineered recession. He takes the credit for it. The reality of all of these figures is that something positive has to be done. Not only are the figures disastrous, but also the level of hidden unemployment is disastrous. There are something like three quarters of a million hidden unemployed in Australia and there are almost half a million under-employed, as I indicated from those earlier figures. When those figures are taken together, they lift the number of Australians who are either unemployed or under-employed, all of whom want work or more work, to something like one in every four Australians. It is an horrendous and appalling figure for which this Government has no answer, for which the Democrats only want to give bandaids of handouts of government money. There is no attempt by the Government to have a basic structural correction of this disaster. Instead, it will be throwing money at the problem, which it will borrow from foreigners or rip off taxpayers, without solving one basic thing.We know perfectly well that throwing money at the problem is not the solution. One of the former top men of the Treasury, Dr David Morgan—who has now gone to Westpac—has said exactly that. It must be very embarrassing to the Government to know what Dr Morgan is saying. In a recent Westpac publication he dramatised the difference between the 1982-83 recession, which he said was a combination of external and domestic factors, and the 1990-91 recession, which he said was purely domestic. Dr Morgan said:The main catalyst for the 1990-91 recession in Australia was the Governments imposition of high interest rates aimed at curbing rapid growth in domestic spending (primary business investment).But the seeds had been sown by the Hawke Governments mishandling of the recovery from the 1982-83 recession as most of the gains in reducing inflation during the recession were lost in an over-rapid recovery.That comes from one of the Governments former major advisers who also just happens to be married to a Government Minister, Ros Kelly. He says:This laid the groundwork for the spending boom, high inflation and large balance of payments problem of the late 1980s so that `another recession, this time due only to national problems, became inevitable.That is what Dr Morgan says. What is this Government doing? It is doing exactly the same thing. It is just incredible. It has learnt nothing. It will do nothing that is aimed at correcting the basic problems. Instead, it is leading us into exactly the same sort of disaster that it led us into after the last recession.We, on the other hand, have a clear policy which does create jobs. We have heard the Government talk about the 800,000 jobs theoretically that would be bought with other peoples money under its One Nation program. We will create the structural change. We will get rid of seven taxes that are hitting industry. We will create a situation where the Government is off the backs of Australians. We will get rid of the pressures that the Government has imposed on the business sector which limit its capacity to expand and which restrain it from employing people. Can one think of a more stupid tax at the moment than payroll tax, a tax on employment? (Time expired)

name: Senator POWELL
content: —The matter of public importance which has been placed before the Senate today by the Australian Democrats, the failure of the Keating One Nation statement to provide for adequate action to reduce unemployment, is a very important debate. Prime Minister Keatings One Nation statement was supposed to be about jobs but, despite a bit of window dressing and some rather obvious bribery, One Nation does very little for those already unemployed and those Australians living on low incomes.Senator Tate did not much like the analysis put forward by Senator Spindler in the first instance on behalf of the Democrats, so I will give him a couple of other opinions. Tim Colebatch in the Age , immediately following the release of the One Nation statement, made the following point:The Government needed a much bolder, bigger package than this to fulfil its responsibility to the unemployed. It allowed itself to be fenced in by the expectations of the financial markets.Kenneth Davidson, economics editor of the Age , in his comment following the release of One Nation gave the statement a `Good in his somewhat school-report-style article. He went on:But it seems to me that in a situation in which the economy is running at about $20 billion a year below capacity, one of the biggest contributions to improving economic efficiency would be to place first priority on getting as many unemployed working as possible.I thought Senator Tate would like to have a couple of further opinions, Basically, the Government has failed to seize the moment and do what is most desperately needed—create employment.One Nation reflects a government that has resigned itself to a high long term unemployment level. The statement predicts unemployment falling to 7.5 per cent in 1995-96. When put up against the Fightback opposition figure of 8.2 per cent by 1996, unemployed Australians are surely entitled to ask, `Where do we fit into either of these so-called grand visions for the future?. The fact of the matter is that both the Governments and the Oppositions packages blatantly consign at least 700,000 Australian workers to the unemployment scrap heap. Is it any wonder that voters in next weeks Wills by-election are turning away from the two major parties as they realise what a bleak future is being served up to them and to their children.Let us be very clear what we are talking about when we discuss employment statistics and percentages. We are talking about the lives of 700,000 Australians—their lives and the lives of the people who depend on their incomes. They are being disregarded and callously brushed aside as the necessary economic fallout of the recession we had to have. Senator Baume, in his contribution to this debate this past 15 minutes, has talked about unemployment as a cancer in the Australian economy. I would much prefer to hear Senator Baume or anyone else referring to that as a cancer in the Australian society.It is this aspect of One Nation that the Democrats find most abhorrent: the willingness of the Government to accept that 700,000 or more Australian workers and their families will bear the brunt of the so-called economic reform. This is the human face of the recession. This is what the Government and its advisers do not seem to want to see or hear. They do not seem to want their consciences ruffled by the countless stories of misery and heartache engendered by unemployment. They, it seems, want to continue to see unemployment as a neat little economic and statistical dilemma—`the problem of the hour as ANU professor of economics Ross Garnaut dismissed it two weeks ago. Professor Garnaut is the proponent of drastic tariff cuts—an annoying diversion from the main game.Tim Colebatch, one of the few journalists who is taking an interest in what lies behind the statistics, observed in the Age last Friday, March 20, that:The media seems bored by unemployment, avidly reporting the views of 25 year olds in the financial markets while largely ignoring the devastating consequences these policies have on hundreds of thousands of Australians. Many economists are no better: weary of trying to line up the four goals of economics—high growth, high employment, low inflation and a balanced current account—they have decided that only inflation and the current account matter, and growth and employment are dangerous distractions.Unemployment is far from being just a distraction. It is the major long term economic and social problem facing this country. In the past two years the numbers of Australian unemployed for nine months or more has risen by more than 200,000. In a little under 20 years we have seen the number of Australians who have been out of work for six months or more go from 6,200 to 443,200. It is still rising by 15,000 people a month.To accept these high levels of unemployment is to ignore two very fundamental issues. Firstly, it ignores the suffering behind the statistics and, secondly, the many hidden and increasingly not-so-hidden costs of unemployment. Welfare agencies throughout the country—not lobbyists here in Canberra as the accusation has been made of the Democrats earlier in the debate—tell of the helplessness and despair associated with unemployment: of family breakdowns, suicide, children going hungry; of longer and longer queues for emergency relief and food packages; of homeless families; of young unemployed people turning to crime and drugs; and the increasing sense of alienation and exclusion from society.We have never carried out proper accounting of the cost to our society of continuing to tolerate long term unemployment—not just the cost in human equality and dignity, not just the cost to welfare budgets of the State and Federal governments, but the additional costs incurred by our police forces, prisons, hospitals, drug clinics, schools and so on. The predicament faced by our young people, for example, is reflected in alarming statistics on teenage suicide, youth homelessness and juvenile crime. Here is the clear evidence of the costs on the other side of the ledger.What about the costs to the country of the waste of talents of those people? What about the costs of juvenile crime estimated at $1.5 billion a year, or the cost of adolescent suicide estimated at $100m a year? Mr Keating and Dr Hewson, in all their posturing in the Wills by-election, need to bear in mind that, in that northern region of Melbourne, the majority—over 50 per cent—of those young people are out of work. It is time that both Government and Opposition acknowledged the costs on the other side of the ledger.The wider community is coming to realise that we need to spend money to save it. Are we going to refuse to pay, knowing that we will have to pay much more in the future? Are we going to refuse to pay now, knowing that the costs are not just measured in dollars but also in the dismal futures we are passing on to our children?We should note again that if there is an upturn—and this is looking longish term—in employment, it is areas such as those surrounding Wills and the northern region of Melbourne that will be among the last to reap the benefits. I think that we can look to the year 2000 for any relief for those people.If one million Australians are to be scapegoats for our economic woes, the Government should at least ensure that those people have sufficient incomes to live on. In reality, that is not occurring. In fact, we have seen a series of measures over the last two years, strongly supported by the Opposition, that have quite clearly penalised or disadvantaged people who are out of work through no fault of their own.Although there have been some gains in the area of improved access to training programs, the Government has basically been engaged in cost cutting, tarted up as an active employment strategy. We have seen young unemployed peoples incomes reduced. At the height of the recession, we saw social security waiting periods lengthened, forcing people to wait even longer for that income support. A new liquid assets test was introduced, forcing people to use up their meagre savings before they can receive any assistance.We have seen the Newstart scheme introduced, with its draconian approach to the unemployed. This scheme signalled that the Government was intent upon undermining the principle of unemployment benefit as an entitlement and a compensation payment for the inability of the labour market to provide adequate income through employment. That principle of income support as a right is an important one and one in which the Australian Democrats believe very strongly.The Government has missed many opportunities with its One Nation statement. It could have increased the amount that people on pensions and benefits are permitted to earn before losing their entitlement to payment; it could have reinstated young unemployed peoples incomes back to adult levels; it could have stopped penalising unemployed people for doing voluntary work; and it could have reduced or removed all existing waiting periods for income support, which are responsible currently for much poverty in this country, especially among families. But the Government did none of things.Mr Keating might like to drop into Wills to try to convince the electorate that there are real significant differences between the Government and the Opposition, but the workers in Wills will bear in mind the reality of Tweedledum and Tweedledee. name: Senator SHERRY
content: —The matter of public importance we are discussing today, which was proposed by Senator Spindler on behalf of the Australian Democrats, is:The failure of the Keating One Nation statement to provide for adequate action to reduce unemployment.Firstly, I will respond to some of Senator Powells comments. Frankly, I do not need to be reminded of the effects of unemployment. My father went through the Great Depression of the 1920s and 1930s. When I was a child, he recounted to me fairly regularly the effects of that Depression. This is not an uncaring Government or, for that matter, an uncaring Opposition. I believe that every person in this place, although our approaches, policies and philosophies may be different, genuinely does care but perhaps has a different attitude from the Australian Democrats. Later in this contribution to the debate I will be making further comments about the economic approach of the Democrats.The One Nation document tabled by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) contains a wide range of initiatives. It is a four-year plan for reinvigorating the economy of this country. It includes a range of issues and initiatives such as the big projects initiative; the development of railways, ports and roads; the continued development of our aviation policy; changes to the tax rules and depreciation regime to encourage infrastructure; and active interventionist approaches in the areas of tourism, the motor vehicle industry, banking, research, export industries, workplace reform, education and training and, of course, personal income tax cuts without a consumption tax.These are some of the areas that the One Nation document covers. I do not intend to comment on all of them today; I intend to concentrate on some general comments about Budget deficits and economic policy in general. I also intend to make some comments about education and training and the labour market; the tourism industry; large projects; and then conclude my remarks with specific comments primarily aimed at the Democrats, although I will be touching on the so-called Fightback package proposed by the Opposition, particularly in my reference to the development of the tourism industry in this country.I also think it is a bit ludicrous of the Democrats to be moving this motion at this time. With the best will in the world, even if the Opposition were able to implement its Fightback package—if it ever gets the chance, and let us hope it does not—I do not think even it would seriously expect there to be any significant reduction in unemployment one month after that packages implementation.

content: —I will deal with the provisions in a moment. In terms of Budget deficits, some criticism has been made by the Opposition that we are borrowing money and using other peoples money to pay for the Budget deficit to fund much of what is contained in the One Nation package. All I can say to that is: so what? This Government has run a surplus in government expenditure for most of the years it has been in office. That is to its credit, because that was an appropriate policy at that time.The One Nation statement proposes to increase the deficit by $2.3 billion to $6.8 billion. That is a quite substantial and responsible fiscal stimulus to the economy. We reject the comments made by those opposite that it is inappropriate to have a substantial Budget deficit at this time. We have run a surplus over much of this Governments period in office, when we had a much lower rate of unemployment, and we are now running a significant deficit.We would draw the line with the Democrats on the size of that deficit. I am not sure what they are proposing—again, I will comment on the Democrats at the end of my contribution—in terms of a Budget deficit to carry out the sorts of propositions that they have in mind. I am sure that Senator Kemp, looking at the cat-like smile on his face—while he is chewing something, I note—will refer to the Democrats proposed budget that was handed down last year. I am sure that he will be drawing out some of the inconsistencies in the Democrats approach as I will be at a later date.In terms of education and training and the labour market, there are very significant pronouncements made in the One Nation package. They build on a succession of changes that have been initiated by this Government over the last nine years. It is certainly fair to say that there is criticism of education and training and labour market initiatives in themselves for not solving unemployment straight away. That is certainly a legitimate criticism. But in the longer term of the Australian economy, it is very important that we upgrade the education and training levels of our work force. A consistent feature of every major OECD nation is that they have very highly trained and educated work forces. The education and training levels of the more successful economies, such as Germany and Japan, which are quite often quoted, are much greater than our own.In the last nine years this Government has had significant success in this area. The year 12 retention rate increased from 41 per cent to 71 per cent last year. There has been a 50 per cent increase in the number of students attending universities. In the years 1992-94, we will be spending $13 billion in this area. In fact, there has been some criticism that we have been too successful in the university area and have neglected some areas of education and training. The number of university degrees has increased by 43 per cent.I referred earlier to the criticism that is being made about university education. A legitimate criticism which can be made of this Government and the States is that the number of persons studying in the trade area has declined—the number of trade qualifications has declined by 11 per cent over the last year. I do not believe that is an outcome that we can be pleased with. In the One Nation package the Government has proposed to switch the emphasis from universities to the TAFE sector. It has proposed a quite revolutionary approach; that is, for the States, particularly, to take away the funding and control of the TAFE sector and provide an additional $720m over the next triennium for the TAFE sector.This has been backed up by two reports specifically commissioned by the Government: the Deveson report, which drew attention to the diverse and responsive training system that is needed; and the Finn review which, amongst a variety of issues, showed that 30 per cent of school leavers who go into the work force have no additional vocational education and training. The One Nation package picks up, in a positive way, on those reports and funds some initiatives to try to resolve these two issues.The Employment and Skills Formation Council, led by Laurie Carmichael, recently brought down a report. As I understand it, Mr Carmichael will be speaking to a number of parliamentary committees on that report later this week. Also included in the One Nation package is funding for an extra 9,000 apprentice places in 1992; an additional 10,000 traineeship places; and an additional 7,000 places in the apprenticeship system for those most at risk during the current economic recession. Jobstart will attract an extra $100m in funding.This Government can be quite proud of the changes made in the tourism industry over the past eight or nine years and the success that has been achieved. One of the features of the One Nation package is that the Government has targeted, in a positive way, a number of sectors of the economy where there has been and is likely to be significant job growth in the long term. In 1991, 2.4 million visitors came to Australia. There was no growth at all in most countries with comparable economies. In the past eight years there has been a 155 per cent increase in the number of tourists coming to Australia.In terms of export dollars—and I stress the words `export dollars—tourism is worth $7.3 billion to this nation. Tourism is our largest single export, constituting 10 per cent of the total value of our exports. It is worth more than wool, wheat, meat or iron ore. It provided 50,000 new jobs in the past year and it will provide 200,000 new jobs over the next eight years, as the Democrats would have learnt from the answer given in response to the question asked by Senator Sowada during Question Time today.We propose to go further in the area of the tourism industry. A number of initiatives have been outlined in the One Nation package. For example, there will be deregulation in the aviation industry to encourage the continued expansion of that sector that has occurred over the past couple of years. The promotions that have been undertaken over the past eight years by this Federal Government through the Tourism Commission are well known to us and have been very successful.Initiatives contained in the One Nation package include changes to depreciation. The depreciation regime in the short term accommodation area has been improved to 4 per cent a year; it was previously 2 1/2 per cent a year. We have broadened the assets that can be covered by the depreciation schedule to include such things as car parks, roads, runways, shelters and seawalls. The rate of depreciation on very expensive plant and equipment items in the hospitality industry—such things as furniture, fittings and air-conditioning—has been significantly improved from 13.5 per cent to 20 per cent. There will be additional funding of $6m for the Department of Tourism, and $5m and $10m for the Tourism Commission over the next two years.A feature of the tourism industry has been the very significant growth of visitor numbers from Japan, Korea and other Asian nations. We are now the No. 1 preferred destination of persons coming from the US, Japan and New Zealand. That is a tribute to the previous Minister, Mr Simmons. Whilst the current Minister for Tourism (Mr Griffiths) has held his portfolio for only a short period, he has made very clear his very great interest in the tourism industry.I was not going to refer to the Fightback package in any detail today. However, I have to mention the cataclysmic effect that the Fightback package will have on the tourism industry.
