content: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague) —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 24 of 1991-92, Department of Administrative Services, 1990-91 Financial Statements of Business Units.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PARER
content: —by leave—I move:That the Senate take note of the document.As a general comment I would like to say that, yet again, I think the Auditor-General has shown he is worth every cent he is being paid as the guardian of taxpayers money; he has produced an excellent report. By way of background, let me explain that the Department of Administrative Services is now made up generally of a lot of business units. A few years ago it was decided that these quasi-commercial units would be established with type 2 trust accounts.As part of that process the various business units moved into accrual accounting which, I might say, was well overdue and actually welcomed by the Opposition. This meant that proper balance sheets, profit and loss, notes to accounts and so on were produced. This represented a difficult transition for government departments which were not used to accrual accounting and all the things that come with business enterprises; they were used to government accounting. The Opposition was only too happy to display a degree of patience in the transition because we recognised the difficulties of moving from government accounting to proper financial accounting through the accrual accounting process.However, as pointed out in the report, of the six business units the Auditor-General in fact has qualified three. Very important and not often generally recognised is the number and amount of assets owned by the taxpayers and covered by the Department of Administrative Services. The six business units themselves, as pointed out by the Auditor-General, had a total operating revenue of over $1 billion in 1990-91 and assets totalling over $1 billion.I will just speak very briefly on some of the audit findings because, even though the Opposition is happy to display a degree of patience, the report shows the difficulties and—I suppose I could put it this way—the lack of regard in the past for the sorts of things that are awfully important when running a business. In fact, I would have to say that if the degree of record management displayed by the departments was carried out in the private sector, not only would those particular business enterprises be in serious financial difficulties, but also, I think more importantly, we would see—and quite legitimately—the financial press write very disparaging remarks within its financial pages.I just touch on a couple of the points raised. The Australian Property Group provides accommodation services and property owner services to government agencies. In 1990-91 it had total operating revenue of $52.8m and expenses of $44.7m. In a summary of the audit findings, the Auditor-General pointed out the areas requiring managerial attention. One was the need to review and reconcile unissued sales invoices for Commonwealth-owned properties totalling some $3.7m to ensure that debts were recovered or bad debts written off, as appropriate. At any time, but particularly in a time of recession, this would be of utmost importance if these were operating as private sector operations.Other comments were made with respect to the reconciliation of records of Commonwealth-owned properties to ensure that all rents and outgoings were recovered from tenants; in other words, collecting rent. The Auditor-General talked about improved cash management by prompt allocation of cash receipts, improved credit note controls, more defined debt recovery and so on. There is also substantial criticism of the key computer system, MENTOR, to reduce the risk of incorrect processing of financial information and tighten data input.One of the things the ANAO found is that the property register contained large amounts of obsolete and incorrect data, especially in relation to the Commonwealth-owned estate. This is a matter that I have raised a number of times in Estimates committees because, again, the Audit Office noted that Australian Estate Management maintained a separate property management register instead of using the MENTOR property register. So we had two arms of DAS using different systems to record property, which is a major asset.In fact, in the last Estimates Committee hearing, I requested a list of all the properties owned by the Commonwealth Government; subsequently that list was provided to me. But I noticed, for example, that there was a major property—maybe the list did not include land on which buildings were not built—in the City of Brisbane which is next door to the Commonwealth Government Offices which was not included on the asset register. This casts some doubts on the validity of the asset register itself and, of course, asset registers are absolutely vital in the operation of any commercial operation. When one has doubts about the asset register provided by the Commonwealth, I believe it to be a very serious matter.In regard to the Australian Property Group, the Auditor-General also noted that it issued over 4,600 credit notes totalling $120m in 1990-91, and that there was a control weakness relating to the use, allocation and control of those credit notes. The report states:Audit testing disclosed that credit notes were issued to. . . write off bad debts.I expect that this practice will be corrected following the Auditor-Generals report. Again, I wish to pay credit to the Auditor-General for drawing attention to these commercial operations. The report suggests that the practice of bad debts being written off in this should cease, and the Department has indicated that it will do so. Once bad debts are written off against sales by using credit notes, the provision for doubtful debts is understated. In proper accrual accounting procedures it is most important to be able to estimate such provision. The report further states:The correct classification of properties within the property registers is important to enable the correct calculation of rentals and charges and to help ensure adequate control over properties.This is a basic requirement for any organisation and the Auditor-General has drawn attention to this fact.Another matter of great concern to me was that the audit found that a number of users were assigned privileged password access to the computer operating system facilities beyond their operational requirements. The report states:This excessive level of access could enable a user to manipulate intentionally or accidentally the MENTOR database without the changes being detected.This is another matter that must be addressed by the Department.I turn now to the Australian Government Publishing Service, which provides printing, publishing and distribution services to the Parliament, as well as advice on those matters. The audit found that there was a need to establish a stock accounting system for passport and related documents. I will enlarge on that in a moment. The audit also found that finished goods holdings need to be analysed to ensure obsolete items are identified and written off where appropriate, and that there should be a timely reconciliation of print brokerage jobs to ensure that sales and associated costs were identified. The concern about passport related documents was that, even though the ANAO building itself is secure, it was found that printing blocks for those documents were not kept in a secure place within the production unit and were readily accessible. This leaves itself open to abuse of the passport system itself.In regard to the AGPS, the report further states:The audit disclosed that approximately 40% of the total finished goods value related to items dated 1988 . . .The level of obsolete stock is of great concern. One of the problems in any commercial operation—whether it be in the private or public sector, but more importantly in the private sector—is that as time goes by in the commercial operations of organisations such as DAS, if obsolete stock remains on the books it artificially inflates the profit figures. In fact, more than one public company has found itself going down the tube into liquidation because it has maintained on its assets register very high levels of obsolete stock which could not be sold. In addition, in regard to publishing a lot of stock would take up valuable space, which in itself attracts a rental.The Auditor-General conducted an audit of the Australian Construction Services which is broken up into two discrete groups, Project Services and Asset Services. Project Services provides architectural, engineering, design and construction services, including fitting out and refurbishing government-owned and leased accommodation. Asset Services provides asset-management services, including repairs and maintenance and minor construction works and fitout. In 1990-91 the total operating revenue for the ACS was $582m and total expenses were $593m, representing a loss of $12m.The Audit Office conducted a review of procedures and methods used by various ACS State offices to account for construction work in progress. The review found that methods and procedures used did not comply with the requirements of the Australian statement of accounting standards. I make the point that during the transitional period time must be allowed, but that time has now passed. We must look very carefully at the 1991-92 figures to ensure that these transitional problems have now been eliminated.The ANAO found that although the ACS made accurate estimates of the revenue it received—which is important—the costs were not matched in a manner which took account of the total estimated cost of each project. Again, this supports a concern that I expressed during previous Estimates Committee hearings that many of the charges being made were not based on a cost structure. Any organisation knows that if quotes given to obtain work are not based on a cost structure, it is inevitable that sooner or later the business will be in trouble.The Audit Office noted that while asset registers were maintained in the ACS, they could not be fully relied upon because comprehensive stocktakes had not been undertaken. In other words, no check had been made of assets. This shows the problem of operating under a government accounting system and the benefits of moving towards a proper accrual system based on business principles. The Audit Office made a recommendation that most businesses would take for granted, namely, that there should be some identification numbers to assist in the recording and control of assets. I do not know how any stocktake can be undertaken—whether it be on fixed assets or whatever—unless that simple practice is carried out.The Australian Surveying and Land Information Group provides government agencies, the general public and the private sector with surveying, geodetic, mapping and land information services. In 1990-91 its total operating expenses were $52m and its total revenue was $44m. I am quoting these figures to show that these organisations are not small businesses. They are large businesses and, in the event of their being unable to operate profitably, the taxpayer must pay. Hence, there is a necessity for these organisations to be run in a proper and businesslike manner. The ANAO commented that AUSLIG had not undertaken a comprehensive stocktake of assets for several years. If my memory serves me correctly, some asset adjustment was made last year, because asset valuations were given at the time of the transfer of assets to these commercial operations which were then found to be too high.Again, this raises doubts in our minds—bearing in mind the accountability of these organisations to the Parliament—as to how factual is the information provided to us. AUSLIG advised that it will undertake a stocktake and revaluation and that this would be carried out before 30 June. We look forward to seeing that in the estimates during the Budget session.The Auditor-General made the following simple recommendation concerning the Australian Protective Service:A base for costing of APS operations needed to be established to facilitate better cost control . . .That is simple, and is the sort of measure that anyone would expect to find in any business operation. However, because of past practices of government-owned operations, it is difficult to undertake during the transition process. The Australian Protective Service provides guarding, custodial and security services to government departments, and the report stated that in some cases services had been provided in excess of those costed. Again, that is the sort of error that would not be tolerated in the private sector.It was also pointed out that with some clients there were no written agreements. So I guess that if there were no written agreements, there was no understanding of what service had to be provided, over what time span, and so on. This, of course, is very important because if, at some time down the track, it is decided that this sort of exercise would be best done by the private sector, one of the more important parts would be to have contracts or written agreements with customers so that one could evaluate the business itself.Another point that is raised—and it is raised in a few other parts of the Auditor-Generals report—is the need to review the policy of capitalising all asset items over $500 for financial reporting services. The remark is made—to which I would generally agree, although I still also believe it is important to keep a track of assets—that for low value items it can lead to the unnecessary capitalising of all assets. That is, again, a practice that is generally frowned on within the private sector, not only from the point of view of inflating the figures, but from the point of view of moving items which are expense items into capitalised items and thus, as I mentioned earlier, unnecessarily inflating the figures.The final audit was carried out on the transport group and this covers Comcar, Fleet, distribution services and removal services. The summary of the audit findings was that a reconciliation of key accounts and the general ledger was not being undertaken on a regular basis, and the procedures for the recovery of outstanding debts continued to be a problem.I will pursue that further in another place, but let me just make an overall comment. First of all, the Auditor-General has yet again done an excellent job. It is hoped that he has sufficient resources at his disposal to continue to do this sort of work. But it shows that Government enterprises have all the earmarks of operations where there is not the same incentive to contain costs and maximise revenue as exists within equivalent operations within the private sector. This does not signify in any way any criticism of the individuals within those commercial operations. It shows that the system is at fault because the incentive does not exist to ensure that there is a profit, because there is always a recognition that at the end of the process, if debts are not collected, if a profit is not made, the individual commercial operation can go back happily to the Minister for Finance and seek that money to be funded—not by the Government, in fact, but by the taxpayer.Question resolved in the affirmative.

content: —I move:That this Bill be now read a second time.I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .Leave granted.The speech read as follows —This Bill, seeking appropriation of some $204m, is introduced to accommodate special circumstances arising from the Governments Statement on the Economy & Employment last November and the recent One Nation Statement and to ensure continuity of funding for other important Government initiatives. The Bill addresses only 3 items of expenditure—Labour Market Program Assistance to Jobseekers and Industry, Residential Care for Older People and Child Care Fee Relief—continuity of which the Government considers can not be jeopardised by the timing of the availability of funds being dependent upon passage of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 through the Parliament. To await passage of that Bill in the normal course of events would place severe hardship on many individuals, companies and charitable organisations. This is not the Governments intent.In short, payments for these measures are required in a timeframe which, on the basis of current estimates, cannot be accommodated by the advance to the Minister for Finance whilst awaiting passage of the Additional Estimates. Put another way this Bill principally deals with the timing of payments for these key Government programs.In light of the Appropriations being sought in this Bill, an amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 has been moved in the House of Representatives in order to remove from that Bill reference to additional appropriations for these programs. The relevant portfolio Program Performance Statements provided in connection with that Bill will be amended to reflect the changed appropriation arrangements. In that regard, by seeking Parliaments agreement to accelerate separately the appropriations required for these three programs, the Government is responding to the urgency of needs that cannot await passage of the other Additional Estimates in the normal course. I recognise that the Senate, through its Estimates Committees, will exercise its customary scrutiny over the range of Government programs in the course of considering Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991—92.I turn now to the specific programs:LABOUR MARKET PROGRAM ASSISTANCE TO JOBSEEKERS AND INDUSTRYThe Governments Labour Market Assistance to Jobseekers and Industry is aimed at assisting the unemployed retain their skills and links with the workforce, which is particularly crucial at the present time.The Government announced an increase of $71m in the program for 1991-92 in the November Economy and Employment Statement and a further $11m net has been provided in the One Nation Statement. Smaller increases in related programs, totalling $5m, result in a total appropriation now being sought in this Bill of some $87m, which has been removed from Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 as I noted earlier.RESIDENTIAL CARE FOR OLDER PEOPLEThe Governments Residential Care for Older People program is directed to ensuring that aged and disabled people, who are assessed as being unable to live at home, have available to them residential support and care appropriate to their needs. As part of the program, grants are made to religious, charitable and other organisations to defray the cost of capital works. An amount of $50m is proposed in this Bill, reflecting a faster path to construction for approvals given. An amendment moved to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 has removed an equivalent amount from that Bill.CHILD CARE FEE RELIEFThe Governments Child Care Program assists families with dependent children to participate in the workforce and the general community, by ensuring child care is affordable for low and middle income families and by improving the supply and quality of child care. As part of the program, fee relief payments are provided quarterly in advance to service providers to defray the costs of child care for low and middle income families.This program, unlike the majority of initiatives where individual entitlements are met from Standing Appropriations, is currently funded through the Annual Appropriation mechanism. In light of the entitlement nature of the program the Government is considering in the longer term whether to establish a Standing Appropriation for the program.The appropriation sought in this Bill, some $67m, largely reflects an increase in the average amount per place for fee relief since the Budget estimates were derived and a higher than expected number of child care places being available in 1991-92. An amendment moved to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 has deleted some $43m originally sought for this program in that Bill. The additional amount of some $24m sought in this Bill reflects updated calculation of the amount required, undertaken since preparation of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92.I wish to emphasise again that this Bill seeks to provide appropriations for programs to ensure eligible individuals and organisations are not disadvantaged and placed in a position of hardship pending passage of the Additional Estimates Bills. We have brought forward a specific Appropriation Bill rather than proposing an increase in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to fund these programs pending passage of the Additional Estimates. By taking this path the proposed appropriations can be scrutinised by Parliament prospectively.I commend the Bill to the Senate.

name: Senator SHORT
content: —Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92 is a Bill that this Government has introduced very suddenly into the Parliament. It came into the House of Representatives last Tuesday or Wednesday. I think it was debated very rapidly through the House of Representatives on Wednesday 25 March, and it is now here before the Senate.The Bill is an extraordinary Bill and it is an unprecedented Bill. It is seeking appropriation of some $204m. In the second reading speech it is said to be required:to accommodate special circumstances arising from the Governments statement on the economy and employment last November and the recent One Nation statement and to ensure continuity of funding for other important Government initiatives.The Bill seeks funding for three of the Governments programs. First, $87m is required for a labour market program assistance to job seekers and industry. Secondly, $50m is required for residential care for the elderly. Thirdly, $66m is required for child-care relief.The thing that makes this Bill unprecedented is the fact that the three items for which appropriation is being sought are already included in the Additional Estimates Bills—the additional Appropriations Bills or Additional Estimates Bills as they are called—currently before the Senate: Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1991-92. Those Bills, as we are all aware, are being subjected to the normal Additional Estimates processes in the sense that they are being considered by the six Estimates Committees of the Senate, and that process is proceeding in the normal way. The Government is proposing to amend Appropriation Bills Nos. 3 and 4 to withdraw from them the three items that are now to be included in Appropriation Bill (No. 5).The Governments explanation as to why this unprecedented action is being taken is that there is insufficient money in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to meet the spending requirements for these programs over the next few weeks in the event of there being a delay in the processing through the Parliament of Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. My understanding from the Minister for Finance, when he raised the matter with me before taking his proposals to his Cabinet—and before consideration of it in the Oppositions shadow Cabinet last week—was that if there were to be a delay in the Parliament passing Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 beyond 7 May, there was a real risk that the Government could run out of funds to meet those programs, and that therefore this action was being taken to be on the safe side, because they were urgent programs, despite the fact that they are not new programs. As the second reading speech says, two of them arose out of the Government statement on the economy and employment last November, and the third one is one that is included essentially in the One Nation statement introduced by the Government on 26 February and, of course, could have been included, as most of it was, in Appropriation Bills Nos. 3 and 4. So we are not talking about something that suddenly happened.The argument seems to be that, if we get this Appropriation Bill (No. 5) through quickly—and, as I understand it, the Government is seeking almost to have it through the Senate today—there is no risk of those programs being starved of funds in the event of the Senate delaying beyond early May the passage of Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. At least, that is my understanding of it from what the Minister for Finance told me.The way in which this matter is being handled raises some very important issues. It is only four weeks since Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 were introduced in the normal way into the Parliament. Nothing has happened since then to delay in any way the consideration by the Parliament of those Bills. They moved through the House of Representatives in due process, they came to the Senate in due process and they are being considered by the Estimates committees in due process. There has been no delay in any of that consideration.So the first question that arises is: why, if there is the need now for Appropriation Bill (No. 5), was that need not foreseen just four weeks ago when Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 were introduced? What has happened since then to cause what appears to be, if the Governments actions are anything to judge by, a sudden crisis in funding—the Government running out of money to fund three of its important programs? No explanation has been given to the Senate, and it was not given to the House of Representatives, as to why this was the case. At the very least it is incumbent on the Government to tell us why it has been required to take this—I repeat—unprecedented action. Never before, as I am aware or as I am advised, has the Parliament passed an additional Appropriation Bill which comprises material already in other additional Appropriation Bills currently the subject of consideration in the Senate. So the Government must provide an answer to that question.It would appear, on the face of it, that the Government is, at the very least, guilty of gross incompetence and financial bungling in its preparation of Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. If it is not, then why did it include these programs in Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4? It knew the timetable and the sequence under which they would be considered. Nothing has happened to change that timetable or that sequence. If those programs were included then, and now the Government finds it needs a special Appropriation Bill, prima facie, one would have to say that there has been a bungle—of a management or financial administration nature, at least—on the Governments part, and the Government needs to answer that question.The next question that arises is: how is it that the Government could find $317m for a one-off bribe to voters nine days before the Wills by-election on 11 April, to pay a one-off family allowance payment to try to buy votes in the Wills by-election? The Government found that $317m through a Bill amending the appropriate legislation, and that Bill was passed here on 5 March. How come the Government could get all of that in order for this one-off payment announced in the so-called One Nation statement—really the `One Nation, One Job statement, namely, Paul Keatings job—yet not have the wit to be able to manage the appropriate funding of three ongoing programs that it has had on the books and known about, and which have been there for a lengthy period of time? There is something very funny about what appears to have happened—not funny ha, ha, but funny strange. The Government does need to tell us why that appearance of strangeness, at the very least, has occurred.I am not suggesting, because it certainly appears not to be the case, that the Governments requirement to pass Appropriation Bill (No. 5) is in any way related to its need for $317m for Thursday of this week to meet its bribe payment of the family allowance to voters. I am not suggesting that there is a mechanical link. But even if one were not a particularly suspicious person, one would have to ask the reason for the apparent unseemly haste in the requirement to have Appropriation Bill (No. 5) passed this week, when we know that that payment is required to meet the Governments bribe commitment on 2 April. These are some questions that need answering.Another question is: even if there is a funding problem over the next few weeks in relation to the three programs that are the subject of Appropriation Bill (No. 5), why may they not be met? We are only talking about a three-week delay, or thereabouts, at most; a delay which should not really be considered a delay because it is something that the Government has known about all the time. Why not meet those payment requirements over the next few weeks, if such need arises at all, from the Advance to the Minister for Finance?The Government says, as I understand it, that there is no money in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to meet that expenditure. That is a pretty strange thing anyway. Why is it that the Advance to the Minister for Finance, at this time of the year, is so bereft of funds that it could not meet the expenditure on these programs over a very short number of weeks? We are not talking about money to fund programs until 30 June. We are talking, according to the Government, of finding money to pay for programs between now and, say, early May.There are two questions: firstly, if there is no money in the Advance to the Minister for Finance, why not? Secondly, how is it that the Minister and the Government have told the Parliament that there is no money, when my staff were advised by the Department of Finance at 4 oclock last Friday that the current unused balance in the Advance to the Minister for Finance, so far as Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is concerned, for which there is an appropriated amount of $170m, is $92.4m? So far as the Advance to the Minister for Finance in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) is concerned, for which the appropriated amount is $140m, I am told that there is a current balance of $128.2m.If those figures from the Department of Finance are correct, it makes even more strange and, quite frankly, incomprehensible the actions of the Government in bringing in this unprecedented Appropriation Bill (No. 5). If the figures and the advice I have been given are wrong, then it is incumbent on the Government and the Minister to tell us whether those figures are wrong. If the situation as I have portrayed it today is not the case, then we need some answers. If the situation as I have portrayed it today is the case, there would appear to be no valid reason for the Government having taken this unprecedented action of introducing Appropriation Bill (No. 5).It is because of those factors and concerns of the Opposition that I will be moving a second reading amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 5). The amendment is still being processed, but it would be along these lines: whilst not opposing the Bill, the Senate, firstly, condemns the Government for its incompetence in not recognising the crisis it was facing in funding these programs; secondly, condemns the Government for being able to make a one-off bribe payment of $317m prior to the Wills by-election, whilst at the same time claiming not to have the $204m of funds to fund established programs; and, thirdly, refers the Bill to Senate Estimates Committees B, C, E and F—I think they are the relevant Estimates committees—for their consideration of the items contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and for report on those items to the Senate on our first day of sitting after the forthcoming three-week break, namely, 28 April.To the Opposition that amendment seems to be perfectly reasonable because those items that are the subject of Appropriation Bill (No. 5) are already contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), which are being considered by those very Senate Estimates committees at the moment. Therefore, it would make sense to follow the same Senate Estimates committee procedures on this occasion.The proper thing for an Appropriation Bill of this nature is for it to be considered in Senate Estimates. There have been examples in the past where that has not happened. For example, last year there was a special additional Appropriation Bill to cover the Gulf War and wheat payments associated with the Gulf War at that time. The essential difference between that situation and this situation is that those items were not included in existing additional Appropriation Bills before the Senate. In this case, as I keep saying, they are.They are the things that I wanted to say in relation to the Bill itself. I repeat: it is an extraordinary Bill; it is an unprecedented Bill. The coalition thinks that much more explanation of the reasons for this Bill is required before it should be further considered. For that reason, I would hope that when the Minister sums up this second reading debate he will answer those questions. Even if some of the points that I have raised are satisfactorily answered, I would expect that the Senate, if it is really carrying out its parliamentary role properly, would agree to refer the Bill to the appropriate Senate Estimates committees for their consideration.I hope that the Australian Democrats will see the logic of that approach. I hope very much that they will support that referral to the appropriate Estimates committees because, frankly, if we do not, the Senate will be letting down the people of Australia and we will not be undertaking the responsibilities with which we have been entrusted.The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns) —Senator Short, I take it you will be moving that amendment formally?

name: Senator SHORT
content: —I foreshadow the moving of that amendment. If it does not turn up in the next 10 minutes, my colleague Senator Reid will formally move it during her comments.Whilst not wanting to debate the content of the Bill in any more detail—it is a Budget-type Bill, as Appropriation Bills are—there are some things that one should appropriately say about other matters concerning the state of the economy and matters which are of great concern to us as we continue in the deepest recession that Australia has had in the last 60 years. The Australian community is now looking at the relative merits of the two major sets of competing proposals that have been put up, on the one hand, by the Opposition in its Fightback proposals and, on the other hand, by the Government in its so-called One Nation statement. They are issues of great moment for the future of Australia. They are issues on which the electorate needs to be as well informed as possible so far as their content is concerned.Before saying some additional things about the coalitions Fightback package, I wish to pick up a statement that was on the AAP wires today from the National Australia Banks chief economist, Mr Julian Pierce, concerning the likely future growth of the Australian economy. What Mr Pierce is saying today is absolutely in line with what the coalition has been saying since the release of the Governments economic statement on 26 February. The Senate will recall that the Governments Budget forecasts for the next four years are predicated on the basis of a real rate of growth in the Australian economy of about 4 1/2 per cent for each of the next three to four years.The coalition has questioned that figure from day one. It seems extraordinarily high. It has rarely been achieved in Australias history. There were faster rates of growth in the couple of years coming out of the 1983 recession but the circumstances at that time were vastly different from those which now exist. Those differences are such as to provide no basis for comparison or optimism that the growth rates now being forecast for the next three or four years by the Government will be anything like those that were achieved coming out of the last recession.This is very significant because the Government, even on the basis of very optimistic forecasts for growth in the Australian economy over the next three to four years, sees very little significant decrease in unemployment. Just as importantly, despite the fact that the Government expects a big increase in revenue because, according to it, the economy will be growing so rapidly, at 4 1/2 per cent real for each of the next three or four years, it still forecasts an accumulated Budget deficit over the next four years, including the current financial year, of no less than $20 billion. As the coalition has said on many occasions since the 26 February economic statement by the Government, that is financial irresponsibility in the extreme. It means that the Government will have to go to the financial markets to borrow $20 billion over the next three years to fund that Budget deficit. That will add about 60 per cent to the Governments existing borrowings in the financial market of this country.The inevitable consequence of that is a significant increase in interest rates, and is on the basis of an optimistic economic growth rate. If the economic growth rate is anything like the level forecast today by the National Australia Banks senior economist—that is a forecast with which I would be broadly in accord and he may be a little optimistic—accepting a figure of 2 per cent to 2.5 per cent for the next year, that would mean that the Budget deficit next year will be several billion dollars higher than the $8 billion that has been forecast by the Government. That will occur at a time when, hopefully, there could be some recovery in the Australian economy in terms of the private sector looking for some funds for expansion and new development. Heaven knows we need that. In the last couple of years Australia has had the largest fall on record in new investment in the private sector.Since the onset of the recession, we have seen Australias investment base and capital base decimated. Therefore, there is a great need for new investment in Australia, otherwise any recovery in the Australian economy and in demand will simply be met by huge increases in imports. If that happens, we will have yet again another balance of payments crisis on our hands. We desperately need new investment. Therefore, we need to take steps to encourage investment in Australia, and have to do everything we can to avoid investment being frustrated. That will occur if we increase interest rates in the way that will inevitably happen as a result of the Governments fiscal policy. Hence, the Governments economic statement of 26 February was irresponsible. Everything in that statement is geared to cause a crowding out of private sector investment in Australia right at the time when that investment is hopefully occurring.

name: Senator KERNOT
content: —The Australian Democrats approach the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92 with one major object—that is, not to debate Fightback, One Nation or even the Wills by-election, but to ensure that the Government is legally able to spend the money which will be appropriated by this legislation.The appropriation, as Senator Short has said, covers child-care fee relief arrangements, residential accommodation of aged people and training programs for unemployed people. The Democrats totally support the provision of child-care fee relief to those low income and disadvantaged groups which currently benefit from the existing arrangements. We also support the residential care for older people program which provides money to religious and charitable organisations for the construction of housing to meet the needs of aged and disadvantaged people who cannot live at home. The construction of dwellings under this program is being accelerated to provide employment. We do not argue with that move.The other programs relate to labour market assistance to job seekers and industry which seek to allow the recently unemployed to retain their skills so that we do not suffer a structural skills shortage in the future. Again, who could argue with the aims of these programs? We will not put at risk any of these programs by delaying the passage of this Bill. We just do not think this should be about political point scoring.The Bill is not part of the ordinary budgetary processes. That is why I would like to look at the processes for a moment. There are precedents which I will cite to show that this accelerated appropriation is not unprecedented. The ordinary practice is that the appropriation Bills Nos. 1 and 2 are introduced with the Budget in August and are then passed in the middle of the Budget sittings. In the Autumn sittings, the supplementary appropriation Bills, Nos. 3 and 4, are introduced. These are designed to appropriate funds additional to those of Nos. 1 and 2 to cover unforeseen expenditure and expenditures on new programs not included in the Budget. In addition, appropriation Bills Nos. 3 and 4 are used to replace funds which have been drawn from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. That is a general contingency fund which temporarily finances urgent and unforeseen expenditure until a specific appropriation has been made. Then we have what are known as Supply Bills, which are introduced at the end of the Autumn sittings which merely provide temporary authority from the Parliament for the normal functioning of the Government from 1 July until the first appropriation Bills are passed in November. That is the process. We have to work out where this fits in.There have been a variety of claims made about this particular appropriation by the Opposition, particularly in the other place. It was said there that this measure is unique and unprecedented. By `this measure I mean the accelerated urgent appropriation. That is not true. The current format for the presentation of appropriations arose from the parliamentary compact of 1965. We should look at examples from that date.The first precedent occurred under the McMahon Government. The Appropriations Bill (No. 3) 1971 was introduced to provide urgently needed additional funding—the same as we have here—for the Australian Wool Commission. In 1973, Appropriation Bills Nos. 3 and 4 were additional Bills which were necessary because of the change to the administrative arrangements orders, to provide funding for the Aboriginal advancement trust and to top up the advance to the Minister for Finance.In 1974, another additional Bill, Appropriation Bill (No. 3), was necessary to facilitate an increase in the pay of Defence Force personnel. The then Treasurer noted that Appropriation Bill (No. 1) needed early supplementation. In 1975 two additional Appropriation Bills covered additional spending because of Cyclone Tracy and the prior Premiers Conference. They were also necessary to cover other items in advance of the normal Additional Estimates. Last year, we had the special appropriation for the Gulf war.So the seeking of an acceleration of funding for existing programs has precedents in 1971, 1974 and 1975. Governments of both persuasions have, on occasion, needed to seek short term funds to continue to provide essential community services—the sorts of community services for which this Bill seeks urgent appropriation. Senator Short has raised a different sort of precedent—the precedent for perhaps pre-empting the Senate Estimates processes. I look forward to hearing the Parliamentary Secretarys response to this matter.The Opposition has also said that perhaps the Bill was necessary because some sort of special juggling is needed to fund the family allowance payment with which it is suggested the Government is attempting to buy the voters in the Wills by-election. But we know that this money has already been appropriated separately by legislation passed in the House of Representatives and the Senate. So the point to be made is that this Bill is not seeking to increase funding.I come back to what I think is the only matter of substance raised by the Opposition, and that is the question of Estimates committees. Parliament does have to approve spending by the Executive and must have the ability to supervise and to scrutinise the details of any such spending proposals. Accordingly, the Senate proposed and agreed to a motion on Friday that the Bill be referred to the Estimates Committees E and F, which will report on or before Wednesday 29 April.I can understand Senator Shorts concern that maybe there is something fishy or that there is some sloppy bookkeeping. But I can also understand the Governments explanation of the need for urgency in the passage of this Bill. The Government says that Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) are not expected to pass the Senate until about 7 May and by that time, it claims, the Advance to the Minister for Finance will have been exhausted and payments for some significant social programs disrupted. So if it becomes clear that Appropriation Bill (No. 5) will not pass both Houses by 2 April, the Government claims it will be necessary to restrict the child-care fee relief payments due on 1 April from being paid quarterly in advance to being paid in advance on a six-weekly basis. I think that is the nub of it. It is claimed that this will cause many child-care providers great difficulty because many services are already experiencing cash flow problems and an unexpectedly reduced payment would aggravate this.The Department of Community Services and Health has service level agreements with over 4,000 services and at least half of these provide for quarterly in-advance payment arrangements. There is a question for the Government about whether it would be in breach of contract if this quarterly advance is changed to a six-weekly one. It is claimed by the Government, too, that, if it is forced to make a six-weekly payment, this would require manual calculation and that it is too late to do this and make the payments by the due date.So, clearly, there are insufficient funds available in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to meet all the expected calls upon it before the normal Appropriation Bills are passed. I think it is normal to anticipate the possibility of other urgent and unforeseen circumstances. So perhaps it can be argued that it is quite reasonable to bring forward additional legislation to ensure that all the Governments obligations and responsibilities can be properly funded. The point, again, is that it is not additional funding; it is simply accelerated funding for projects already planned.We have two competing principles: the principle of concern about a new precedent—the precedent of accelerated appropriation which by-passes or pre-empts the scrutiny of the full Senate Estimates processes—and the principle of worthy projects for which money has already been planned but which are in urgent need of funds. The Democrats approve of the projects in this legislation.Putting to one side suspicions of sloppy bookkeeping and suspicions of fishiness, in respect of which I am looking to the Parliamentary Secretary for an explanation, at this stage the Democrats have decided to support the people who would be affected by the restriction of these funds. We want to make sure that child-care fee relief in particular is paid as expected. But we, as Democrats, wonder why the Government does not simply introduce legislation which makes a standing appropriation for child-care fee relief of the kind that is dealt with in this Bill. Under such an arrangement, this sort of situation would not arise in the future.

name: Senator REID
content: —The Senate is discussing the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92. I say `No. 5 because that in itself is unusual. We are entitled to look at why we have this Appropriation Bill before us. Senator Short has spoken in the debate and advanced some views. Senator Kernot has just contributed to the debate and advanced some views. If one looks at the debate that took place in the other place, at the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), or at the explanatory memorandum, one does not get an adequate explanation of why Appropriation Bill (No. 5) is before us.We know what this Bill is seeking to do. It is seeking the appropriation of some $204m, of which $87m is for labour market reform assistance to job seekers and industry, $50m for residential fee relief for older people, and $66m for child-care fee relief. So we are talking about the unemployed, the elderly and children—all topics of great concern to all in this place.It is interesting to speculate on why this Bill has come before us in this fashion, especially when all of these matters have been largely covered in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which is also before this chamber at the present time. We have the unprecedented situation of matters being removed from another Bill so that their passage can be expedited in the Bill now before us. It may be thought strange that senators should ask for a better explanation. I think we are entitled to such an answer. There is a need to ask why the Government has not followed the normal procedure and has deemed it necessary to introduce the additional Appropriation Bill. In my view, it is not being fanciful to suggest that there is some sort of funding crisis.The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), in his second reading speech, said that the Bill contained the three items which I have mentioned. Referring to the expenditure, he said:. . . continuity of which the Government considers cannot be jeopardised by the timing of the availability of funds being dependent upon passage of Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1991-92. . .If one were sensitive, one could almost take offence at that. He went on to say:. . . payments for these measures are required in a time frame which, on the basis of current estimates, cannot be accommodated by the Advance to the Minister for Finance whilst awaiting passage of the additional Estimates.Who conducts Estimates committees, Mr Acting Deputy President? The Senate does so. Is he suggesting there—and as I read his words, he is—that the Senate has something to do with Appropriation Bill (No. 3) being held up and this money not being available? The facts are that we have not and that can be proved to be the case. He is attempting to word the situation in such a way that it is being implied that the Senate has something to do with this money not being available. It is very clear that this money is not available because of the Governments own mismanagement.It is clear that the Government has no intention of letting this Bill go to the Estimates committees to be dealt with in the proper manner. It has no regard for any of the traditions of this Parliament; it will walk over the Parliament as it wishes. The Executive will have its way. It is time that the people of Australia came to understand the extent to which the Parliament is being totally ignored by this Government.As I have indicated, the Government is seeking to rush through this Bill in a totally unprecedented manner. Shortfalls of funds of this kind are not new—we know that—and they are normally dealt with by an Advance to the Minister for Finance. That source does not seem to be available at this time either. So again we can ask what has happened and what has gone wrong. People would not mind if the Government came forward and told the Parliament honestly what has happened and why it is in this mess. Instead, we are being left to determine it for ourselves.The Minister for Finance claimed in the other place on 24 March:We have brought forward a specific Appropriation Bill rather than proposing an increase in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to fund these programs pending passage of the Additional Estimates.Why is it being done in that fashion? As I said, gross mismanagement is the answer that I come to for the Governments not being prepared to treat this matter properly and put it through the Parliament in an orderly manner.We are in the middle of the recession we had to have. That has been said so often, but let us not forget it. Let us not forget who created it and who said that it was a recession we had to have.Let us go through some of the numbers. They are pretty big numbers and they are a bit hard to accommodate, perhaps, if one thinks in terms of ones own household budget. All of us know what sort of a mess we would get into if we let our household budgets get out of kilter in the way that this Government has been prepared to allow Australias Budget to get out of kilter.The original Budget deficit forecast contained in the 1991-92 Budget was $4.732 billion. Prior to the economic statement, the Government issued a revised Budget deficit forecast of $6.3 billion. I suppose that, if it is said quickly enough, that figure sounds less than the last one. This figure was revised to $6.8 billion to reflect the new measures in the Governments economic statement.According to the most recent statement of Commonwealth Government financial transactions issued by the Minister for Finance, the cumulative Budget deficit to January was $11.2 billion and, by February, $12.2 billion. We are now told to expect a staggering $8 billion deficit for the year 1992-93 and a high deficit for the next four years. An $8 billion deficit for 1992-93 represents eight Parliament Houses. It took us 10 years to build this place and pay for it, but that is what the Government can do in one year.Worse still is the fact that this Government has taken Australia from a forecast surplus of over $8 billion to a deficit of $8 billion in just two years—a turnaround of $16 billion. To me, that is a clear demonstration of the instability and inaccuracy of the Governments budgetary processes.Mr Acting Deputy President, what would happen to your household if you behaved in that manner, in proportion to your income, of course? Your bank manager would have called you in long since and dealt with you.This Bill seeks to meet increases in ongoing government expenditure not provided for previously. As everybody knows, many spending initiatives of the One Nation statement were lifted straight out of the Fightback package. These initiatives and many tax cuts, that is, forgone revenue, are things which the coalition would normally support— they are in the Fightback program—but the difference is that in the One Nation package they are totally unfunded. With these proposals, Australia faces the immediate and medium term prospect of huge increases in debt, with the consequences that we all know about—namely, huge interest rates to be paid and the impact of the exchange rate.The Government is pushing up Australias debt at a time when we can least afford it. The question to be asked is: where will the money come from to fund all the measures in the One Nation statement? It is relevant to note that the Syntec organisation spoke of this. On 25 March, it released its estimation that One Nation will leave Australia with something like $18m in unfunded spending commitments over the next four years and will increase interest rates by 4 per cent, which will cost the business community around $8 billion. Of course, we all know who pays for that in the end, and that is the consumer.The Minister for Finance has claimed—and I have already referred to this—that Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92, the Bill we are discussing today, is necessitated by delays in the passage of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). Clearly, he is attempting to have people in Australia believe that it is the Senate that is holding up the passage of these Bills, thus causing this delay. It is not.The two Bills, the normal Appropriation Bills, were introduced into the Parliament on 26 February this year. This Bill was introduced on 24 March, just one month later. On 25 March, it was decided that they should be debated cognately. What is the reason for this haste? I hope that, when he replies, the Minister will deal with this and tell us why this Bill is coming before us in this fashion.As I said, $87.4m has been allocated for increases in labour market programs. My goodness, how many programs have there been? Can people remember the Priority One proposal? I could spend the rest of my time going through the various schemes and proposals of this Government. One comes and another goes. The Government keeps announcing new programs for job creation while getting rid of the old one, hoping everyone forgets it. Not many jobs have been created through them, though.

content: —None are around now.

name: Senator REID
content: —Yes. An amount of $71m was announced in the November economic and employment statement. We have had a few of these, have we not? There was the Budget in August, and in November there was an employment statement granting $71m. I wonder how much of that money has been spent. A further $11m was promised in the One Nation statement. Do not forget, of course, that when the Government promises to spend money it is taking it out of the taxpayers pocket to do so; it does not have any money of its own. Further increases in related programs for employment amount to $5m, making a total of $87m being sought in this Bill. The programs deal with our horrendous unemployment situation and the appalling lack of investment and profitability which is afflicting Australian industry.Unemployment officially reached 10.5 per cent in February 1992. Seasonally adjusted, 907,800 Australians are out of work. But everyone here knows that that is not the correct figure for people out of work. Over one million Australians are not able to find the employment that they need to sustain themselves and their families. This figure does not include those wanting to work.The CES figures used to be regarded as a reliable indication of unemployment levels until they became so embarrassingly high that they were abandoned. We now use figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, but we all know that these do not include the discouraged and hidden job seekers—well over 750,000 of them.Just look at the ABS survey. People who have worked for one hour in the week of the survey are not counted as being unemployed. Those who have not applied for jobs in the months before the survey are not counted as being unemployed, no matter how many jobs they have applied for over what period. People who lose their jobs but who have working spouses are not counted as being unemployed. Those not able to start work because they are sick, there is a lack of child-care facilities or for some other reason shortly after the survey are not counted as being unemployed. All of us could give so many examples of people we know who are not working but who want to work, who would still like to have jobs, who would wish to be contributing to this country and making their own contributions but are not able to and have thus become discouraged.What is the real percentage? Is it 20 per cent? I defy anyone to suggest that it is less than that. But those are just the numbers. I really hate even just talking about the numbers because it tends to almost hide the real human tragedy of unemployment, especially long term unemployment. There is the young person who says, `Will I ever get a job?. There is the older person—people who are entitled to think that they would be able to work on for another 10 or 15 years—who says, `Am I finished? Have I nothing more to offer?. What about the stress on the marriage, the stress on the family and the household of having one person—be it a young person or an older person—in its midst who is unemployed? There is the loss of expectation, the feeling of letting down ones family, the feeling of being a failure.The numbers do not convey the hardship and the personal distress, the loss of self-esteem, the loss of confidence that every unemployed person faces, especially those who know that they are not even being counted in the unemployment statistics for reasons that I mentioned before. The numbers do not convey the tragedy of a nation with over 260,000 families whose chief breadwinner is unemployed; or the tragedy of over 218,000 Australian children who live in families where no-one has a job; or the 248,000 Australians who have been unemployed for more than a year. Half a million children are living in poverty, 75,000 are homeless and an extra 140,000 families a year have been plunged into extended poverty because of this recession.People who have never had to turn to anyone for help before—people who have given to the Smith Family, the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul—are now having to go to those places and ask for help. The help is being given freely, of course. There are people who have had to sell their homes; whose children have had to change schools, with all the trauma which one knows goes with changing schools, especially in these circumstances. The hidden hardship in all of this is something that this Government does not seem to know about, to understand, or want to know about. Permanent damage is being done to the Australian spirit by this situation and the cavalier attitude of the Government towards it.Yet the Keating Labor Government seems happy to bring in as many red herrings and distortions as it can possibly think of to try to take the focus away from the real issues. It is spending $20 billion, which it does not have, to hide more unemployed in schools and TAFE colleges; to create what would be a few artificial jobs; and, hopefully, it thinks, to win a few votes in the electorate of Wills. Nobody is suggesting that education and training are not important. Let me be absolutely clear that Australia must have a skilled and well educated work force. But once that is done and students have been left in school for a year or two or put into TAFE courses—incidentally, not forgetting the thousands this year who could not get into universities and TAFE courses—unless there are real jobs at the end of it, nothing is actually achieved. Real jobs will be achieved only if we have productivity and profitability amongst the businesses of this nation.The Government talks about creating jobs. Jobs are not created; jobs are found in businesses that are flourishing and expanding. Jobs come as a result of investment, but investment in this country has fallen to a devastating level. Private new capital expenditure fell again in December, taking the decline over the previous 12 months to 14.5 per cent. It has been in steady decline since June of 1989 when our current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) led us into the recession we had to have.It is not just politicians who are saying this. The Confederation of Australian Industry described One Nation—what a name for this man to use—as follows:The economic statement is not about economic management. It is political from top to bottom. . . One ultimately becomes weary of trying to fit all of the pieces into a coherent recovery strategy.A recent survey undertaken by the Australian Chamber of Commerce found that 92 per cent of its members said that One Nation would not encourage them to increase investment. Only 3 per cent said that it would.The One Nation statement contains a proposal for accelerated depreciation. Who took away the previous Fraser Governments depreciation allowance? The Labor Government took away the Fraser Governments 5 : 3 depreciation provisions and the investment allowance. These accelerated depreciation provisions are a good thing in that they reduce business costs by about $1 billion, but they take us only halfway back to where we were, and they are entirely unfunded. Where will the $1 billion come from to pay for this?It is interesting to look at the turnaround of the present Prime Minister on tariff cuts. For an entire decade he has advocated a reduction in tariffs. But come the Wills by-election, what do we find has happened? Let us quote from the Hansard of another place on 12 March 1991, just over a year ago. Mr Keating told the Parliament, in his usual manner:Within this decade, Australia will have renounced once and for all the fallacious doctrine that prosperity can be found behind the insular wall of protection.He went on to say that this package of measures:. . . ends forever Australias sorry association with the tariff as a device for Australias industrial development.It would be improper to suggest that he was lying when he said these things to the Parliament, would it not?The crucial point is that Labors policy has nothing to help businesses offset and deal with the consequences of the present situation in the way that the Fightback package does. Look at Treasurys own figures on the Fightback package. It will provide a saving of over $5.3 billion to manufacturing industries through the abolition of a range of taxes—payroll tax, wholesale sales tax, fuel excise, the training guarantee levy, customs duties and coal export duty.Tourism will benefit, says Treasury, from a saving of $376m to businesses involved in air transport. Again, according to Treasury, there will be a $318m benefit to hotels, restaurants and clubs. Treasurys own figures admit that there will be a $306m benefit to railways and a $1.1 billion benefit to road transport. Treasury estimates that Fightback will reduce the cost of exports—and this is one of the keys to the Oppositions increasing employment—by $1.9 billion or 3 per cent. Those are just some of the savings and advantages which businesses will get from the Fightback package. So it is necessary to look at these things as a whole.The real crux of the debate today and the choice for Australia is: do we accept yet another set of uncoordinated, stop-gap, unfunded, electorally expedient measures as set out in One Nation; or do we choose the comprehensive, integrated proposals set out in the Fightback package? The choice really is very clear indeed.This Bill seeks $50m for residential care for older people. I could talk about Senior Citizens Week which is being held this week in Canberra. Care for older people is important when one looks at the way the population will be ageing. In June of 1989 an estimated 1,860,000 Australians were aged 65 or older, that is, 11.1 per cent of the total population. That figure is projected to increase to about 12 per cent by 2001, and to between 19 and 21 per cent by 2031. Of course, the elderly—the aged—are very important to this country, but we need policies which will enable our country to be prosperous if we are going to properly provide for the ageing population, not these stop-gap measures that we are looking at today. The sum of $67m is sought for child-care fee relief. In dealing with this Bill, the Minister said that it is:. . . an increase in the average amount per place for fee relief since the Budget Estimates were derived and a higher than expected number of child-care places available.This is another demonstration of the Governments gross financial mismanagement in that only $43m was sought in Appropriation Bill (No.3)—which is also before us—but even before that was dealt with, the Government sought another $24m. Did it not know that four weeks ago? It makes one wonder whether there will be a new Bill every month to top up. Child-care, employment and the elderly are all important issues but, to get back to the point that I was making, let us have an economy that is flourishing. Let us introduce the proposals of the Fightback package which will give the economy and the people of Australia a chance to have employment and to have a future. I refer to page 1 of todays Australian , which states:None of the 50,000 extra child care places pledged by the Federal Government before the last election has yet been delivered.It seems that the Government has still not reached a funding deal with the States. It makes one wonder how seriously it takes child-care. It is another example of an unfulfilled pre-election promise and empty rhetoric on the part of the Labor Government.This is a Bill that has been brought in out of step with the normal processes, and with no adequate explanation as to why the Government has run out of money, except for a veiled suggestion that it is the fault of the Senate. It is not the Senates fault, and I have proved that to be the case. The issues within it are significant and important, but let the Government be honest enough to come out and tell the people of Australia why it is in the mess that it is in.

content: —The presentation of Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92 is yet another chapter in the continuing saga of the errors this Government continues to make. The second reading speech really is quite an insulting document to present to the Senate. Here is a speech that simply says that the Government will appropriate $204,415,000, and that by appropriating this amount it will amend the existing Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), which are currently subject to the Estimates hearings.When one looks at the speech and sees the sort of number-fiddling that is going on, one realises that of that $204m, the Government is appropriating only about an additional $24m. If one looks at the program performance statements for appropriation Bills Nos. 3 and 4—specifically those for the Department of Employment, Education and Training—one sees at page 28 under program 4 `Labour Market Program Assistance, sub-program 1 `Employment Access, the appropriation of an additional $71m. When one looks at the schedule of Appropriation Bill (No. 5), one sees that it is appropriating approximately $87m for DEET. If we subtract one figure from the other, we find that all we are getting is an additional $16m for DEET.If one does a similar exercise with the program performance statements for Health, Housing and Community Services, one sees that with regard to `Residential Care For Older People, $50m is being appropriated. Guess what the Ministers speech and the schedule provided in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) tell us? They tell us that the $50m appropriated by the Bills currently before the Estimates Committee will be cancelled out and reappropriated in Appropriation Bill (No. 5). One would have to ask why the Government is doing these things.On page 28 of the PPS document for Health, Housing and Community Services—Program 8 `Services For Families With Children: Child Care Fee Relief—there is a sum appropriated of about $67m. We are appropriating $67m for child-care and subtracting the appropriated sum of some $43m or $45m, which means that all we are getting is an extra $24m.We must ask ourselves why the Government is going through all these gymnastics. The reason is that it hopes to get its hot little hands on the money straight away without going through the Estimates proceedings; in other words, without the appropriation being justified in any way, shape or form. We must then ask ourselves the next question: Why is the Government trying to do that? Why is there this cover-up? Then comes the next question: Where is the money for that promised handout—the bribe of $125 for the first child up to a maximum $250 per family, to be paid just prior to the Wills by-election—coming from? Could one draw a scenario that says that the money is being taken away from other programs and that this money has to be appropriated desperately, otherwise the Government will not be able to meet the bills? Is that what it is? There are no PPS statements for this Appropriation Bill (No. 5).

content: —As I said, we have this bribe that has been contrived to try to buy votes in the Wills by-election. What we have here is a fudge. The proper accountability hearings are being stopped from taking place with regard to the additional appropriation of $40m.If we look at the Ministers statement contained in the two pages of what passes for a second reading speech, we see a reference to the fact that the Government does not want to use the Advance to the Minister of Finance. Page 28 reads as follows:Enhancements to the Employment Access Program (EAP) were announced in the 1991 November Economic Statement. These enhancements were in recognition of an expected growth in the level of long-term unemployment over the next 12 to 18 months and the need to maintain an appropriate level of program assistance for this group. This should help provide the skills needed to take advantage of new job opportunities emerging from the recovery.Further enhancements to EAP were announced in the 1992 February Economic Statement.November enhancements will provide additional EAP places of around 30,000 in 1991-92 mainly in the major components of JOBTRAIN, JOBSTART and Special Intervention.February enhancements will provide approximately 6,660 additional places under the JOBSTART component of EAP.That is $71m for that little lot, yet we are now told that that estimate is wrong. With this Additional Estimates Bill the Government is simply amending the existing Bills which are being properly dealt with.Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8 p.m.
