name: Senator BISHOP
content: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was perhaps giving vent to some of the anger I feel at the way the Parliament is being manipulated by bringing in a fifth Appropriation Bill while Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) are still being dealt with by the Estimates process. Although in this chamber we may use those terms and understand what the debate is about, I am rather concerned that people who read the Hansard ought also to understand the proper method for allowing governments to have money to spend to implement their policies.Basically, governments have no money of their own. They have only taxpayers money. The way they are allowed to spend taxpayers money to implement their policies is by way of money being appropriated—set aside, allocated—for the programs that they outline and which are in some detail published, and which the Estimates committees then scrutinise. This process is gone through twice a year. When the Budget comes down, we get Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2). We have two of these Bills because one is for recurrent expenditure and the other is for capital expenditure. This similarly applies to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), which we get six months later.We regularly have two sets of Appropriation Bills because, when a Budget is brought in, it is nothing but an estimate of what might happen in the next 12 months. It is the Governments best guess or, more accurately, the best guess of the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance of what might happen. As I have pointed out in this chamber before, Treasury gets it wrong every year. Obvious evidence of that is the fact that the Government has had to introduce additional Bills to allocate extra money for estimates that were not quite right. Sometimes an extra amount of money is allocated because of a CPI increase and the additional wages that have to be paid, but there are all sorts of other reasons, such as, simply, errors and omissions. There is a mechanism for that too. At the time Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) are brought in, we also bring in something known as the Advance to the Minister for Finance—and that comes in two parts too.At the time the last Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) came in, there was appropriated—that is, set aside, earmarked—$170m for recurrent expenditure and $140m for capital expenditure. Basically, if the Government suddenly finds that its calculations for any department—not just Treasury and Finance but, say, DEET, that we are dealing with here, and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services—are in error, it has not calculated correctly, there has been an unforeseen event, it can make an application under that Advance to the Minister for Finance to allocate that money to the department until there is a new Appropriation Bill.What is so unusual about this current situation and what makes it so different from last year when we had an extra Bill—the extra Bill was needed to pay for the Gulf war, when we had countries that did not pay for the wheat they had bought from us and there were legitimate, spelt out reasons for needing that emergency legislation—is that, in this case, there is no rhyme or reason contained in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). There are no published additional program performance statements. There is not one iota of sustaining evidence as to why this Bill is necessary.As I pointed out before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, in effect this Bill amends particularly Appropriation Bill (No. 3)—that is the one that makes up for the mistakes for recurrent expenditure—and it wipes out certain amounts that have been set aside, appropriated, for some programs. It appropriates in two cases a greater figure, but in a third case it simply wipes out the appropriated amount and reappropriates it. Why would the Government want to do something like that? Very simply, it has to do with the speed with which the Government wants to get its grubby hands on the money.If we do our figures, as I did before dinner, we see that $71m had already been allocated for the labour market program; now the Government is seeking to wipe that out and reappropriate $87m. In the case of residential care for the aged, $50m had been allocated; the Government seeks to wipe out that figure and reappropriate or set aside $50m. In the area of child-care relief, $45m had been allocated; now the Government is going to reallocate $67m. There seems to be some discrepancy between the figure of $43m that is mentioned in the second reading speech and the figure of $45m that is mentioned in the program performance statement.But, all up, we are talking about a figure for recurrent expenditure of about $40m. If we read the reasons in the PPS notes—they are the explanations as to why the Government wants the additional money—we see that the predictions as to how the economy is impacting on these programs has already been taken into account. As Senator Reid said, these additional Appropriation Bills were introduced on 26 February and here we are in March and the Government is saying, `We got it wrong again by a further $40m.What is the real explanation? Again before dinner, I mentioned the fact that we have this enormous bribe, the one-off payment being made by way of family assistance payment with a figure in the vicinity of $125 for the eldest child going up to a maximum of $250. I have not done the precise calculation as to how many millions of dollars that comes out at, but I do know it comes out at about the sorts of figures that we are dealing with in Appropriation Bill (No. 5).In the event that what has really happened is that the Government has actually transferred money out of other programs for which it has been properly appropriated and, in fact, needs to get its hands on this money quickly, then what it is doing is bringing in a Bill which is designed to get around the proper system of accountability. We could say it is cheating. We could say it is the most appalling abuse of process. Why the hurry; why the speed? Because of the date of the Wills by-election, by which time this Government wants to pay its bribe. What an appalling way to run a Government!But then, why should I be surprised? Only this evening at dinner with the visiting German delegation, I listened to the leader of that delegation make a speech in reply to the speech of welcome. He acknowledged that many discussions on the Uruguay Round were needed. He acknowledged also the need, from Australias point of view, for a reduction in the common agricultural policy, the subsidies that Europe pays that unfairly penalise Australian products. The leader of the German delegation, having seen in the last 48 hours the double back flip which the Prime Minister has tried to do with regard to tariff levels, said, `Well, of course, we all have our difficulties, dont we?—and one could almost hear the cynicism.We have been saying that we wanted a fair deal, yet here we were again trying to do a double flip for the benefit of the Wills by-election. We are sending all the wrong signals to our international trading partners. For years we have been saying, `We are reducing our tariff levels and we want you to reduce the subsidies so that our farmers can get a fair deal. All that work can be undone by the sheer cynical act of a man desperate to hang on.This Bill is perhaps the biggest affront of all time. The Government is trying to race it through in time to get its hands on the money. It is not using the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Perhaps the Government has something else that it wants to use that $92m for. But this is an absolutely disgraceful abuse of the Parliament and the parliamentary process. It is an abuse of the system of scrutiny and accountability. The questions that should be asked about why this money is needed and why the departments have allegedly got the figures wrong need be asked before the Wills by-election and, indeed, before the Bill goes through the Parliament. Yet, this will not happen. The Government will shove and push to try to get this legislation through without allowing any scrutiny of it at all.One wonders and becomes disappointed about many things in the parliamentary process. But, surely, the way in which the Parliament is being treated with the introduction of Appropriation Bill (No. 5) in order to fiddle the books and cheat on the system is the most blatant and sad demeaning of this institution. I move:At end of motion, add , but the Senate:(a) condemns the Government for its incompetence in not recognising the crisis it was facing in funding the:(i)labour market programs assistance to job seekers and industry;(ii) residential care for the elderly; and(iii) child care fee relief;at the time of introducing Appropriation Bill No.3 and Appropriation Bill No.4 in February 1992; and(b) condemns the Government for making a one-off bribe of $317 million prior to the Wills by-election in the form of a family allowance payment at the same time it claims not to have $204 million to fund established programs.

name: Senator MACDONALD
content: —I am pleased to support the amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 5) moved by Senator Bishop and referred to by Senator Short. I was particularly interested to hear Senator Shorts very lucid explanation of the Bill, what it is about and why it needs to be referred to a committee for further investigation. I was also interested hear what Senator Reid had to say about the relevance of this Bill to unemployment.I enjoyed listening to Senator Bishops speech. Senator Bishop asked what the Bill means and she questioned the Government about what seems to be undue haste. I was particularly interested to hear Senator Bishops explanation of how Appropriation Bills work. I was also interested to hear her comments about the Budget being, in effect, the Treasurys best guess of what might happen. I might say that, if one had to rely on the Treasurys best guess, one would be in real trouble. That is one of the problems with this country at the present time. No doubt Treasury advised Mr Keating over the 9 years that he was the Treasurer and is still advising him and his current Treasurer (Mr Dawkins).In the last nine years Treasury has got it completely wrong. The people of Australia appreciate and well understand that neither the people advising Mr Keating nor Mr Keating himself can change their spots overnight. This is the same rotten Government that has given this nation one million people unemployed; a Government that is completely incapable of managing the economy of this nation; and a Government that, through complete mismanagement and incompetence, brought on this recession that it said we had to have. I would suggest that if any further evidence is needed, one only has to look at the Bill before us tonight.I hope that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) will attempt to explain why this Appropriation Bill has to be brought in this month; not even a month after the last of the Appropriation Bills were introduced. One can only wonder why the haste and, as is normal practice, why the matter is not being referred to a committee for consideration. I certainly hope that the Government will allow his Bill to be considered by the relevant committee before it receives final endorsement.Rather than appropriating money for labour market program assistance to job seekers and industry, this Government should be thinking about real jobs for Australians—jobs that will be lasting. Australians need to be given real work. They need a real chance to live their lives as they wish, without worrying whether they will have a job tomorrow. Those privileged Australians who currently have a job should not have to worry whether they are likely to keep it.The Government should completely adopt the Fightback package and thereby provide jobs for Australians on a proper basis. The Government needs to abolish the seven taxes that we have identified in Fightback. This would allow the business world to get going and expand and it would create real jobs. The Government has certainly learnt from the Fightback package and has taken a number of the items that we proposed. But it is not game or able to take them all because it is too much a captive of the unions. Mr Kelty has said that the Government cannot take all of it so, of course, it cannot.The Government has tried to fiddle by taking what it seems to think are the better-looking parts of the package and trying to incorporate them into a document it has called One Nation . Mr Deputy President, you and the rest of Australia know that that statement had nothing to do with one Australia or one nation; it had everything to do with one job and one job only—and that, of course, is Mr Keatings job. Those are the sorts of things that the Government should do. It does not have the courage to do them. It waved its wand and took the best parts of the package. But it has no idea how it will pay.Again, one only has to look at the advice from Treasury to call into question the competence of the people who have been advising the Government for the last 9 years. I do not really blame them. Mr Keating is firmly on record as saying that he had his hands on the levers; that it is all his work; that he is the one who has pulled the levers and directed the economy. I suppose it is only now, because of the anger of Australians at the complete and absolute mess that Mr Keating has made of this country, that he is trying to squirm his way out of it. He is attempting to wriggle out of and shed some of the real blame for the recession that Australia is in at the moment.In the last nine years we have had 16 major economic statements and not one of them has worked. Every year since this Government has been in power we have gone backwards. Of course, neither this Government nor the Australian people can pretend that the sixteenth statement—the so-called One Nation statement—will work. The only way that the dole queues are likely to get any shorter in Australia is if Mr Keating tells the people in the queues to stand a little closer together. The Government has no policies that might do anything about it. Simply throwing more money at training programs and job-seeker initiatives will not achieve what needs to be done.I suppose that if one works on the adage that we learn by our mistakes, Australia can probably rejoice that we have Mr Keating as Prime Minister. He must be the most learned man in the world. He has made so many mistakes over the past nine years that if he did learn by his mistakes, he would be an extremely learned man. As he gets all fired up and excited because there is a by-election coming up, I regret to say that he is proving yet again his complete and absolute incompetence to run this nation.Mr Keating is embarrassed when he gets into Parliament. He knows, that John Hewson knows, that he knows, that he is incompetent. John Hewson does have an idea of where this country should be going. He has a vision, a program and a policy that this nation needs. Mr Keating, by contrast, is nothing but a parliamentary performer; one who goes big on the rhetoric, big on the accusations and big on the name calling, but when it comes to substance, he is just not in the race. He certainly cannot compare with Dr Hewson when it comes to men of substance, men with managerial ability, men with an honesty and a commitment to get this country going.Mr Keatings about-face on tariffs is simply typical. I am pleased to say that Australians are picking up the fact that Mr Keating is simply floating in the breeze. After nine years of saying that we have to have zero tariffs—cut tariffs right down—now, because he thinks it will get him a few cheap votes in the Wills by-election, he is changing his tune. But I wonder whether he will tell the people of Wills that in 1990 when tariff protection reached an all-time high, the textiles, clothing and footwear industry shed 17,000 jobs?Will he tell the people of Wills that, thanks to tariffs, every car sold in Australia costs consumers $4,000 more than it should? Will he go out and say to the people of Wills, `That car you are thinking of buying—there will not be many people, of course, that can even think about buying a car in this economy, but those that might just be fortunate enough to—`is costing you $4,000 more because of tariffs? Will Mr Keating tell all of the people in Wills that across-the-board tariffs cost the average household about $16 per week? Maybe he should tell the people of Wills about those things when he starts vacillating about his tariff protection.The Prime Minister put a lot of his very faltering political credibility on his One Nation statement. But has he truthfully told the people of Wills, who are, to a certain extent, in the middle to lower middle and lower income ranges, just what the serious and credible commentators are saying about him? I will quote Mr Daryl Dixon, a well-known commentator on business affairs, writing in the Sydney Morning Herald on 29 February. He said:Overall, the Keating reforms redistribute real tax burdens towards taxpayers with incomes of less than $26,000 a year in order to distribute large tax reductions to higher income taxpayers. These taxpayers are already favoured in several ways, particularly as emphasised by ACOSS in receiving large tax subsidies for their superannuation savings and by being able to use other tax shelters such as negative gearing and investing via private companies.Is Mr Keating telling the people of Wills about that? The people of Wills, I guess, are in that bracket of $26,000 or less. Many of them would be holding jobs with incomes of less than $20,000 a year. Of course, you might know, Mr Deputy President, as well the people of Wills will know, that those people will get not one ounce of assistance or benefit from this Government in the proposed tax reforms. The wealthy, the higher income earners, do pretty well out of it, but there are not too many of those in Wills. Those on $20,000 a year and less receive no assistance at all when it comes to income tax, or in any other way, out of these packages.Why would anyone believe the man who introduced to Australia the terms, `scumbag, `sleazebag and `spew, and made them part of the vernacular for his Party and for his use in Parliament? Why would anyone believe that man when, for example, two years ago on 22 March, he said, `We wont let there be a recession. Just a year ago, on 21 March 1991, he said, `The worst is now behind us. The Government has established the strategy. In February 1990, he said, `We wont destroy business activity. We wont destroy employment.How incredible is that man? How could anyone believe anything he says? Mr Deputy President, you have friends, as I do, who cannot find a job. You also have friends who are wondering whether they will have their jobs tomorrow. We all know small businessmen who have put their life savings into small businesses. They have worked very hard—80 to 100 hours a week, seven days a week. They have put their everything into those businesses and, through no fault of their own, their businesses have gone bankrupt. Through no fault of their own they have lost everything.Do you know whose fault it was, Mr Deputy President? The man who used to boast about having his hands on the lever. The man who, just before election time, I might say, boasted, `We wont let there be a recession. Then he had the gall to tell us later that this is the recession we had to have. I hope that he is emphasising that as he runs around the electorate of Wills in this by-election; I hope that he is telling those people that this is the recession we had to have. I know from talking to the small businessmen in Wills that they will never forgive that man for what he did to this country.One would think that the Government might have learnt its lesson. If the Government wants to save some money why does it not do so in other ways? I refer to the Estimates that we are about to debate—I am not sure whether they are coming up again in this Bill; who knows what is coming here. It looks like we need an extra $3m as a result of that leadership spill we had to have—the sticking of the knife into the back of Mr Hawke. Because of that, we need an extra $3m to change the staff around. To give the ex-Prime Minister a few extra staff will cost us $703,000. They are only figures; they just roll off the tongue. It is easy to spend that sort of money when it is not your money, Mr Deputy President. I hope Mr Keating has some thoughts of remorse when he thinks about this.Approved salary increases to senior staff in the Ministers offices on reclassification of the former staff of the Prime Minister will cost another $130,000. Termination payments for Mr Hawkes personal staff will cost another $490,000—terminating payments to consultants related to the former Prime Minister, I understand. Getting new parliamentary secretaries, putting them in the job and giving them a few extra staff will cost $703,000.

content: —This evening we are debating Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92. I refer to the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). He said that this is an interim Bill to provide housekeeping money until the appropriations have been scrutinised by the Estimates committees. name: Senator PANIZZA
content: —No, it will not. Appropriation Bill No. (5) seeks an appropriation of about $204m less than a fortnight before the full review and scrutiny by Parliament of Appropriation Bill (No.3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). It is being introduced to accommodate special circumstances arising from the Governments statement on the economy and employment made last November. Special circumstances, yet the statement was made last November!We are still waiting to debate legislation from as far back as March of last year—12 months ago. There is probably some before that, but even I cannot remember everything that this Government does not do. All of a sudden this Bill is important and has to come in here ahead of the Bills being considered by the Estimates committees, yet the special circumstances it covers were announced last November in the statement on the economy and employment and in the recent One Nation package. The second reading speech says it is `to ensure continuity of funding for other important Government initiatives.The Bill addresses only three items of expenditure: labour market program assistance to job seekers, care for older people and child-care fee relief. I can accept that perhaps one of those is urgent—that is, the first one—even though it was first announced in November. But surely the other two can wait less than a fortnight. Senator McMullan probably knows when we will finish Appropriation Bill (No. 3). It is interesting that Appropriation Bill (No. 3) has been amended before we have even got to it, although we have been told that there will be full scrutiny by the Parliament afterwards—full scrutiny after the money has been allocated! That is like trying a murderer after he has been executed, and I certainly hope that never happens.I believe the only urgency in this case is the Wills by-election, which is about 11 days away. The Government is trying to get some good news into the electorate of Wills before that fatal day for the Government. I will come back to the Wills by-election later.During the dinner break I saw an advertisement on television which started off by saying, `It all started in 1983. I did not know what the advertisement was going to be about, but I thought it could have been about the disaster of the Australian Government—that started in 1983. Once I saw that the advertisement was not telling us about this disastrous Government, I did not take much notice of what it was about. That is how any advertisement could start: `The decline of this country started in 1983. I will work on that later.This legislation has come on with five minutes notice, even though it has been around for 12 months. It is the Government putting out spot fires. I do not know whether anyone in this place has ever been a member of a bushfire brigade—probably not, unless Senator Walsh walks into the chamber. The first thing to learn when putting out fires is to attack the whole fire, not the spot fires. That is what this Government has been doing—it has been putting out spot fires and letting the big fire go on and on. As I have said already, we are dealing with legislation that the Government mooted more than 12 months ago.Over the last few months, bit by bit—even you cannot deny it, Mr Acting Deputy President—the Government has been pinching little bits of the Fightback package. The Acting Deputy President is a little on the itchy side tonight. He had a birthday last week, and I thought he might have been in a better mood. I worked out that three people in this place and the House of Representatives were born on the same day and I think we are all cranky. The point is that bit by bit this Government is taking out pieces of the Hewson Fightback package. Senator McMullan is smiling about that.What was said about sales tax today? We in the Opposition were taken to task because we even thought about eliminating sales tax. I read headlines in the newspapers today which said that the Government was going to do away with 80 per cent of the sales tax, or 80 per cent of the people who pay it. That was only the big print. When we read the fine print we will probably find out that the Government has shifted the onus. I may be prejudging the Government—and I do not like to prejudge anyone, including Senator Powell—but I believe that the onus will probably be shifted to someone else.

name: Senator PANIZZA
content: —That is right. The Democrats made a good revelation last week when Senator Spindler supported the use of marijuana—their policies are probably written with the help of a bit of that. Today we saw headlines saying that the Government is moving on the sales tax, yet we were taken to task some time back because we had the audacity even to think about removing sales tax. We were told we could not remove sales tax, yet the papers today say that that is what the Government wants to do.This Government is looking at any angle to get votes in the Wills by-election. I understand that job seekers were allocated $71m in November, $11m in the One Nation package and now more. I have nothing against that. My heart goes out to job seekers the more I see of the harder hit areas of Australia in this recession. Fortunately, I come from an area where we can ride the recession. It is an area rich in farming. Wheat prices have improved greatly in the last 12 months. When we planted last years crop, to be harvested last Christmas, we expected about $120 a tonne and, fortunately, we finished up with $180 a tonne.Wool has improved. We are in the centre of a big goldmining area, even though the gold price is not so good and the mining industry is being knocked around by this Governments gold tax. Other measures have also knocked it around. It is an area where we can see the recession, but we can ride it. But it is soul destroying to go into areas such as the Wills electorate, and some electorates in Perth, and talk to people who have copped it from the recession, and I will refer to them later.I can understand the Governments urgency with regard to job seekers, but as far as the other two areas are concerned, child care and the elderly, surely the appropriation can wait for a few weeks. Residential care for older people has not accelerated in the last week to the extent that suddenly the Government needs the money and cannot wait for the next two weeks. Child-care relief is the same. Have things fallen over that much in three weeks that the child-care relief cannot wait for the scrutiny of Parliament? Everyone is silent on it. This Government is putting out spot fires and, of course, looking to the Wills electorate.I will speak a little on the Wills electorate. I have spent a day in that area. One of the reasons I went into that area was that a lot of people there have a background similar to mine. Even though I say so myself, they are people who look after themselves and certainly know how to endure. I started off by talking to businessmen. I did not necessarily pick ethnic businessmen, but as I went through a shopping centre, they all seemed to be there. They all tell the story that when they first migrated they worked in the factories, in transport and the like. Their eventual aim—after bringing up a family, building a home and paying off the home completely, but perhaps still educating children—was to try their hand at business. That went along quite well for a while until this recession came along. Now they are battling with whatever is loaded on them.Of course, the Victorian Governments going broke has added to their woes. It is ever increasing the land tax and every tax it can. Those costs are loaded on to the lessee. The terms of a lease state that when a shop in a shopping centre is leased, the lessee takes on the obligation to pay the rent and the land tax. That is normal and he accepts it. But when a lease is signed for five years with an option—there is generally a review of the rent period when the lease is renewed at two-and-a-half years—the lessee pays when the land tax and the water rates double. He also pays a share of the electricity costs for public lighting—not just for his consumption of electricity—when they double and treble. They are things that the Government has not taken into consideration.Whereas these shop owners were employing one or two girls, now the husband and wife are in the shop or perhaps it is just the wife trying to keep the business going while the husband is trying to get a job if he can. That is the sort of thing you see. I talked to them about business and talked to the people who came into the shops. The downheartedness of the people is certainly heart-rending and soul-destroying to see. I come from an area which is tough, but we can generally do something to help ourselves.I talked to a person who had migrated as a very young person and started working in factories. He lost his job three years ago. Over the years in this place I have always been a critic of the unemployed, as I have always believed that if people are genuinely looking for work, they can generally get it. But I can see that in a big electorate such as Wills, people with a socioeconomic background of working in factories—factories that were not able to keep up and were not able to be competitive and export on the world market—just cannot get jobs. Senator Faulkner may understand this if he has that sort of electorate in Sydney.I have always reckoned that with an unemployment rate of up to 5 per cent, there are those who do not want to work and I suppose society can carry them. We now have a 10 per cent unemployment rate, one million people unemployed, and there has to be something wrong. Responsibility for this rate of unemployment can be laid right at the door of the Government because of the policies it has had since 1983. So I certainly learnt a lesson by spending a day in the Wills area. Anyone who has not had the experience, I believe, should go there and see how people are feeling.This Government took over in 1983 with a Prime Minister who had been head of the ACTU for a number of years before that. We had the golden fifties and the golden sixties; we had a part of the seventies that was golden; and then the former Prime Minister took over the ACTU. There was a big wage push which caused inflation and away things went. He was rewarded with a prime ministership and he had a Treasurer who gave us the recession we had to have. What did he get as his reward? He got the prime ministership, aided by half of those opposite and half of the Government members in the House of Representatives, plus one, two, three, four or something like that. He was rewarded with the prime ministership. As far as I am concerned, if Mr Keating wanted to be Prime Minister, he should have been elected by the people. Having toppled Mr Hawke as Prime Minister, he should have immediately gone to an election to get a mandate. I am sure everyone knows that he would not have got a mandate. Of course, now we have a recession.Let me get down to the Wills electorate and the textile factories and so on. The Government has changed its tune on tariffs in the last week because it is expedient for the Wills by-election. The Government has been saying that it has a better tariff reduction policy than the Opposition. I thought that at least it might have had an equal period of reduction, but suddenly the Prime Minister, Mr Keating—because of the Wills by-election and because he thinks it will build up his popularity—has weakened on tariff reduction.Senator Button has blamed McEwen, Fraser and Menzies—those good Prime Ministers over the years—for having too much protection. But let history judge that protection. Let history also judge what has happened since 1983. If there is any reason why the factories of Australia since 1983 have been let run down so that they cannot compete with the rest of the world as far as production goes—just leave too high wages aside—it has been the investment allowance that this Government cut out. The depreciation schedule was also wrecked by this Government. There was a good depreciation schedule which encouraged people in business, in factories, on farms and in mines to reinvest in equipment.The only thing wrong with Frasers investment allowance was that he did not have the investment allowance portion on Australian-made goods. I always reckoned that that was his mistake, when we had some factories in Australia manufacturing heavy machinery, agricultural machinery and mining machinery. If he had kept that investment allowance on the Australian-made portion, with a good depreciation system on the rest, what came in from overseas, as he had, that would have been the ultimate position.Senator Walsh from Doodlakine in Western Australia reckoned that there were too many rorts in the system, so the investment allowance went out and the depreciation periods were extended. That is why factories have been let run down. That is why mining plant has been let run down. If people go out into farming areas now, they can see that farming plant is getting too old. Even when the good seasons or the better prices come back, it takes a long time to build up farming plant. In the meantime, dealerships that import that farm machinery have gone into liquidation for other reasons to do with the way in which the Government has run this country. One of the reasons a lot of farm machinery dealers go into liquidation has been the fact that farmers have not been able to purchase equipment.It is the same in the mining industry. When this Government slapped on the gold tax, the immediate reaction was to stop exploration. Once general exploration stops, the next thing is that the exploration drill stops. I know that 80 per cent of the drilling contractors in Western Australia are now in liquidation. That is the result of the gold tax. The miners tell me that they are not doing badly because, even though the price of gold is down, their product is high graded and they are able to extract high class ore. However, in Western Australia the amount of exploration involving drilling has gone down, as has maintenance. That is where this Government has gone wrong. The industry has declined not, as Senator Button said, because the Menzies Government retained tariffs for too long, but because of this Governments investment allowance policies.I am sure that most honourable senators and Treasury officials have read the Hewson package properly. In fact, each time that the Treasury looks at it, it gives the package better and better reports, particularly since the Treasurys first disgraceful exhibition on the ABCs Four Corners . Every day that passes the Treasury comes out with a new snippet from the Fightback package to make its reports on the package much better.The job losses have been not only in those textile factories of Melbourne, but also where there are many highly educated people. I know the approach of the Government and others to unemployment—and I totally agree—is to poke a lot of money towards education. I applaud the Government for that because the best thing for those who are unemployed, either generally or within a particular field, is to educate and train themselves for something better when opportunities come along. So one cannot blame those in semi-professional and professional jobs who lose their jobs for not being trained, because they are trained.I will give some examples of what I know has happened in a couple of accounting firms in Western Australia in the past few weeks. There are some accountants within these firms who have been employed for three to seven years. At four oclock on Friday afternoon, a fellow comes into one accountants office and says, `I want to see you. At 5 oclock, the accountant walks out with his termination pay, a reference and holiday pay. He is out the door. He had spent five years in the place, but was gone within an hour. Firms can no longer afford to employ people like that accountant. It is tragic for these employees and for their families. These people were educated and they trained for their jobs.Another example is in the banking system. Some of those involved have a shorter length of education, but in that industry the same sort of thing is happening. Girls and boys, and men from 25 to 45 years of age, are getting what they call the `green folder. During the day a supervisor will go to an employee and say, `Come with me. The employee is taken in, given a half an hours debriefing or words of encouragement, and is given a green folder. It contains a reference, a pay cheque, a superannuation payment—or whatever the entitlements are—and a cab charge. Such employees are told to catch a cab home and not go back to their desks. Their access code to the banks computer is wiped out, so they cannot get back or get their mates to go back and do some damage to the computer.These things are happening every day. My life has been insulated from such things. As I said before, I live in the country, where people can do something for themselves. But it is heart-rending to hear stories of people who live in cities with large populations. Those present are employed and most of our children are employed. I can say `Thank the Lord that my four children are employed, but these things are happening to the next door neighbour and to those around the corner. It could happen much more quickly to many of us present if this Government were to call an election.This Bill has some merit in its attempt to speed up the reform of the unemployment and labour situation. The other two elements of it could have waited. However, I return to where I started. This Government has been putting out spot fires since 1983. It has not attacked the full avalanche of fire. It is no good taking the Hewson package bit by bit hoping to convince the people that these problems will be solved. This Government must be dinkum if it thinks that this One Nation package is right and that Mr Keating can be Prime Minister for the next three to five years and turn this country around.Last week I spoke to the Western Australian Farmers Federation, which is experiencing problems in certain areas. I got up and spoke about finance, and I said, `This recession will not last for ever. Even I believe that—and mostly I am a super optimist, otherwise I would not be growing wheat with a 13-inch rainfall.I know that Dr Hewson as Prime Minister can turn this country around, but if Mr Keating thinks he is the one who can and if he thinks he has the backing of the Australian people, let him go out to a full election tomorrow, not just a by-election. The Wills by-election was caused by the retirement of the former Prime Minister after he was unloaded unceremoniously by his own people. He had to get out of Parliament or the House of Representatives would not have settled down. Having read Senator Robert Rays remarks about Mr Speaker in the Sydney Morning Herald the other week, I do not think things have settled down 100 per cent. But we will let that go by.If Mr Keating thinks he can do those things, he should go to a full-blown election. Perhaps he will get an idea of how successful he will be from the Wills by-election. Unfortunately, he will get that much of a shock in the Wills by-election that he will not go straight away to a full election, but will want to hang around at least until 19 December so that 12 months is up. He might leave it a bit beyond that because, if I am correct, I believe that the election can be delayed until May next year.If the Government thinks it can turn the country around, let it go to a full election. I believe that the people of Australia will do what deserves to be done to the Labor Government for what it has done since 1983. They should put Labor members into isolation for the next 30 or 40 years. Dr Hewson will then turn the place around. I invite the Government to go out and give it a go. If it cannot do it, it should let Dr Hewson have a go. If we do not turn Australia around in the next 12 months or so or start doing so, we may as well all turn in our citizenship, pack up and try our luck in some other place.

name: Senator McMULLAN
content: —I thought I should start my remarks in summing up by reminding anybody who happens to be listening, or who might subsequently might read reports of this debate, that we are talking about Appropriation Bill (No. 5). It would have taken a great deal of imagination for anybody to actually work that out. There has been only the most passing reference to it during the past hour and a bit and in most of the debate beforehand.In my comments I shall try to put aside some of the misunderstandings that people seem to have about the origins of this Bill and some of the conspiracy theories that abound concerning its origins, and then comment briefly on the second reading amendment that is being proposed and the other proposal concerning a reference to committees.The question that was asked was: `If there was a need for Appropriation Bill (No. 5), why was it not perceived beforehand?. This question was first raised by Senator Short, who would be well aware that the Additional Estimates are drawn together after the close of the Budget session when the annual Appropriation Bills have been approved by the Parliament and are introduced early in the autumn sittings for consideration by the Parliament. Since 1980-81 those Bills have not passed the Senate and received royal assent until May or early June.I use the point to clarify a bit of the elastic imagination around the place that somehow or other if we did not pass Appropriation Bill (No. 5), the other Bills would be passed in a fortnight. That is very interesting because we have not even got those Appropriation Bills before us yet. The Estimates Committee has not reported back and even if all the Estimates committees finish on time, the Parliament will not get the opportunity to start considering them until 28 April. That is the first day on which we can start the second reading speeches, and an optimist might contemplate getting them passed by 7 May. That would be an early date for their passage. So we are talking about—

content: —Two weeks.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator McMULLAN
content: —Senator Shorts arithmetic is not very good.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator McMULLAN
content: —That is not the same as a fortnight in terms of paying bills to people. So, first of all we have to appreciate that we are talking about a significantly different period of time.Following the introduction of the Additional Estimates on 26 February, the Department of Finance sought from departments and agencies details of potential calls on the AMF on the basis of a normal passage of the Additional Estimates, that is, a normal timetable. It was only after this review that a potential excess demand for recourse to the AMF became apparent. So that review was conducted in the normal process. The fact that there may be an excessive demand on the AMF—that is, the Advance to the Minister for Finance—became apparent and remedial action was necessary.That raises the question: why can we not just draw on the AMF, pending passage of the Additional Estimates in a few weeks? The most important thing to remember is that moneys can be spent only for the purposes for which they have been provided. Therefore, a lot of this talk about the way money might be appropriated here to finance promises that were made and funded by quite separate legislation with regard to the One Nation package is entirely misconceived.Brewing in the minds of some who see conspiracies in every matter is another conspiracy here. I would say to Senator Bishop in particular—she is wont to seeing these great conspiracies; and I heard her outlining her conspiracy theory here this evening—that when we see sinister plots, conspiracies and underhand tactics in everybody elses motivations and in everything they do, it tends to be a reflection of that which motivates the viewer rather than the viewed. When we think we are perceiving other peoples motives through a window, I suspect we are often looking into a mirror. I think that is very much the circumstance on this occasion.The Additional Estimates are not going to be passed within this sitting fortnight; that is obvious to everybody. Let me use child-care fee relief as an example. The practice required by contractual arrangements is that payments are usually provided quarterly in advance to defray the costs of child-care to low and middle income earners. Almost all the amounts sought in the Additional Estimates will be due to be paid on 1 April or, at the latest, in the first week in April. So we cannot just pro rata the expenditure throughout the period up to the end of the financial year, or even up to the time of the passage of the Additional Estimates, and assume that resources will be available.So can I firstly dispel the conspiracy theory and explain the circumstances in which we found the need for these Additional Estimates. Everybody would prefer to never have to introduce such a thing as Appropriation Bill (No. 5), but it is a reasonably minor matter in the great scheme of government and economic management. Those who wish to make allegations of incompetence need to be a little careful about the standards of competence which they set for themselves. First of all we had people throwing around the allegation—I think Senator Short said it at a press conference—that, somehow or another, this money is actually required only because we have to have it; we have had extra calls on expenditure for family allowance and the family allowance supplement generated by the One Nation package. Quite clearly, that is not the case, as I have outlined. The appropriation for that flowed from legislation already passed by this Parliament—legislation especially required for that circumstance. It was not out of these appropriations, nor was it from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, nor could it have been. So there is no conspiracy theory. The competence question on that matter remains with the Opposition.Senator Alston also gave one of his more learned displays of his knowledge of government finance in this area. Somehow or other he had discovered that there was a $69m under-expenditure in the area of labour market programs. Recently he asked my colleague Senator Cook why, in view of this, we needed an extra appropriation. He even put out a news release on 24 March to that effect. I do not know who his source is in the Department of Employment, Education and Training, but he should say to that source, `Please explain your documents a little better, because lawyers cannot always understand things. Quite clearly, Senator Alston did not. There is absolutely no basis for this claim. He has made this wild allegation which I suppose is based on a leaked document from somewhere. Maybe someone sent him a bogus document; more likely, someone sent him a legitimate document and he failed to understand it. There is absolutely no basis for the claim that there will be an underspending of $69m against the $454m provision. In fact, we do require the Additional Estimate that is coming forward tonight. It is just another wild flight of fantasy from those opposite.People have also made remarkable assertions that neither Treasury nor the Department of Finance ever get the Estimates precisely right. That has to be one of the most ridiculous comments of public life. Nobody has ever got to the situation where all the assumptions that have to be built in to calculate expenditure, to make expenditure estimates—which is what they are—have been right. Everybody gets it wrong every year. This is inevitable for three reasons: firstly, the assumptions can never be perfect; secondly, the circumstances will change and evolve during the year; and thirdly, there are questions of policy change. Governments cannot set policy only once a year, on Budget night, and never have another change. Circumstances change; governments have to adapt to meet changing circumstances.For those reasons, we will always require Additional Estimates. There is nothing extraordinary about that. It is not a question of people getting it wrong. It is a question of the necessary modification that has always been required in public finance in every country of common political origin, every Westminster system style government.We then come to the question of a concern about the loss of accountability if the items contained in this Bill are passed, rather than being referred to a committee. It is important that we have proper mechanisms of accountability in this Parliament. At this stage we do not have that; we have to rely on Estimates committees, which is very much a second best form of accountability. The problem that people perceive in this accountability question is a product of their obsession with Estimates committee hearings as the process of accountability and the fact that we do not have adequate alternative mechanisms.There is no question of manipulation here. Every dollar of public expenditure will, and should be, referred to an Estimates committee for scrutiny. We support that; that has already happened. It will need to go there; it should go there; we support it going there. But it is grossly irresponsible to contemplate deferring the passage of this legislation so that that review can take place beforehand. Inevitably and necessarily, that would mean that the Government would have to renegotiate the payments; for example, it would have to cease or curtail the payments for low income child-care relief. The one thing that Senator Bishop said in her speech that was correct was that the Government does not have money of its own; it only has money which is appropriated by the Parliament. It cannot spend money that has not been appropriated. If we have not appropriated money for that child-care fee relief, then the Government has no capacity to meet those necessary and socially desirable payments.The programs will be available for scrutiny. They will be referred to the Estimates Committee. The departmental officers will be available to be examined about those programs. People could only believe this procedure to be entirely inappropriate—and the extra Appropriation Bill was dealt with in the same manner last year, when we referred the particulars to the Estimates Committee even though the Bill had been passed—if they have some fantasy about not passing the legislation or not passing the Estimates. That is the only significance of the Appropriation legislation in this one instance being passed in this minor way before Estimates Committee starts to deal with it—or concludes dealing with it, because it may well have started.If we had an adequate, year-round process of accountability instead of this twice-yearly obsession with Estimates-based accountability as the only form of proper review, problems like this would not cause any possible crisis of accountability. Every dollar will be referred to the Estimates Committee. Every program will be available for the scrutiny of the Parliament. That is as it should be and as it will continue to be. It will not be affected by the passage of this Bill.While people and governments would prefer never to have to introduce Bills of this sort—it would be neater and more elegant if it did not occur—there is no question that any of the conspiracy theories have a foundation. This is a necessary piece of legislation to fund necessary and socially responsible expenditure. It is appropriate for the Senate to deal with it with due speed so that those contractual and socially responsible commitments of government can continue to be met. By passing the appropriations funding, the Commonwealth will continue to meet its obligations in these three areas without any loss of accountability or proper scrutiny by the Parliament. At the same time we will know that we have passed the appropriations that will enable these socially responsible programs to be funded and these Commonwealth commitments to be met.I urge the passage of the Bill. I really do not think that the second reading amendment deserves significant consideration. It is just one of those tired old cliches. I could have a bit of fun with poor old Senator Shorts attempt to rehash the GST debate in the second reading debate, but I think he was only trying to pad out the last five minutes of his speech, so I will let that go. There will be other occasions. I understand that he is embarrassed by the impact of the data that is being distributed in Wills. I do not intend to divert the Senate at this time of the evening. I will attempt to have the Bill passed and then get on with other legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.Amendment agreed to.Amendment (by Senator Bjelke-Petersen ) proposed:Omit all words after `that, and substitute `further consideration of this bill be postponed until the receipt of the reports of Estimates Committees E and F on or before Wednesday, 29 April 1992.

name: Senator SHORT
content: —The amendment moved by Senator Bjelke-Petersen proposes to postpone further consideration of the Bill until the receipt of the reports of Estimates Committees E and F on or before Wednesday, 29 April 1992. It is only a few days ago that the Senate resolved to do just what this amendment is calling for. Last Thursday, 26 March—and this is recorded in the Journals of the Senate for last Thursday at page 2128—Senator Tate, on behalf of the Government, tabled various documents, including particulars of proposed further additional expenditure for the service of the financial year ending 30 June 1992 in respect of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Senator Tate, by leave, moved:(1) That the Particulars of proposed further additional expenditure. . . be referred forthwith to Estimates Committees F and E for examination during consideration of particulars of proposed additional expenditure for 1991-92.(2) That the committees report to the Senate on or before Wednesday, 29 April 1992.Senator Bjelke-Petersens amendment in effect calls for the Senate to abide by the resolution that it adopted only last Thursday.In his comments tonight, Senator McMullan said that the Government would abide by the Senate Estimates processes and would allow full scrutiny of the proposed items of expenditure, but that that scrutiny would take place after the Bill containing the items had been passed by the Parliament. The whole process of the Estimates procedure—the whole process on which the Senate operates so far as its scrutiny of expenditure is concerned—is such that the Senate assures and satisfies itself that the expenditure contained in legislation is appropriate before it passes the necessary legislation.The Government now proposes to turn that process on its head. Senator McMullan is saying that the Government has a problem, so we should pass this Bill and then look at the items. If that is done in the Estimates Committee, all honour will be done because the Estimates Committee procedure has been adopted. Whether the Estimates Committee finds fault with the expenditure will not really matter because the Bill will have been passed.The suggestion that there should be consideration of expenditure proposals after a Bill has been passed makes an absolute mockery of Senate procedure. It is a denigration of the Parliament. It is a classic example of the arrogance of the Executive and of this Governments total disdain for the Parliament. I wish Senator McMullan would listen to this because I think he rightly regards himself as a parliamentarian who respects the proper processes of the Parliament. Given that he does regard himself as a parliamentarian—with some justification—I find it extraordinary that he should propose a procedure which prostitutes the parliamentary processes and places the Executive above the Parliament in the consideration of what is, perhaps, the most important of all roles of the Parliament, and that is the proper scrutiny of the expenditure of public money. It shows a total disdain for the processes of Parliament.I hope that the Democrats will understand and accept that proposition. We are not seeking to frustrate the Government in its program. This is a Budget-type Bill. Of course, the Government will get its Bill. But it should get its Bill in accordance with following the proper procedures of the Parliament—the long established processes which this Parliament has fought hard and long over many, many years, indeed throughout its history, to develop, and those processes of which this Parliament rightly has pride.The role of this Parliament is to keep the Executive honest, and to assure itself that money is properly appropriated and the expenditure proposals are examined to the satisfaction of this Parliament before legislation is passed. No amount of words, on behalf of the Government, proposing that we turn that whole process absolutely on its head can disguise the fact that what the Government is proposing to do here is a total travesty of the whole of the parliamentary process.The Australian Democrats have prided themselves—and I know we are often very critical of their lack of sticking with this—that they are going to keep us all honest, keep the Parliament honest, keep political parties honest. If we were tonight to agree to follow a procedure which was contrary to the long-established—and for very good reasons long-established—principles and procedures of this Parliament in relation to the scrutiny of public moneys, we would create a grave crime against the Parliament and against the proper interests of the Australian people.I do not know whether there is a conspiracy in this. I do not know whether there is any relationship between the Governments requirement for $317m by the end of this week to pay its bribe to electors in advance of the Wills by-election. As I said in my remarks today, prime facie there is not a relationship between the two. But I know that it is very suspicious, and I know that the action that the Government is proposing in Appropriation Bill (No. 5), to bring in a new Bill and, at the same time, amend Bills within the Parliament and in the normal process of parliamentary scrutiny, is unprecedented in our history.I raised several very pertinent questions about this in my speech on the second reading today. I do not believe that Senator McMullan has properly addressed those points. I will not go over them all again, but I drew the attention of the Senate to the advice that we had received as late as 4 oclock last Friday afternoon that in the current account, if you like, or Appropriation No. 1 account for the Advance to the Minister for Finance there is about $90m of unexpended funds.We have been told, on the other hand, that the AMF did not really have any funds in it. That is something that has not properly, to my mind, been addressed. There are numerous other questions that I raised which I do not believe that the Minister addressed in his response.So the amendment moved by Senator Bjelke-Petersen is asking the Senate to simply follow long-established principles of this Senate and, indeed, to follow the motion that the Senate passed on the last sitting day—just on Thursday of last week—to refer these items of expenditure to the relevant Estimates committees, E and F, and to await the consideration by those committees of these items and to await the report back to the Senate by those committees on or before 29 April 1992.I note the dates that Senator McMullan referred to in his address, and I note the concerns that he has expressed, but they do not overcome the need to follow proper process. They do not explain, and the senator in charge of the Bill, Senator McMullan, has not explained, how the Government could have got it all wrong—that is what this amounts to—as recently as four weeks ago with the introduction of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) covering most of these items of expenditure. The Government must surely have known then if there was a problem in terms of funding and the timing of funding. If it did not know then, then if there is not a conspiracy involved in this whole exercise—and I am not suggesting that there necessarily is—it reeks of monumental incompetence by the Government in terms of its management of the affairs of this country.The Government is asking this Senate to take unprecedented action to allow the Government to get out of a hole that its monumental incompetence or mismanagement or something else has got it into. It would be a disgrace on the part of this Senate if we were to go along with what the Government is proposing tonight, because it would be a total abrogation of our responsibilities to the people of Australia to ensure that proper scrutiny and examination of proposed government expenditure is undertaken and that we are satisfied on that before we pass legislation involving that.We are not talking about chickenfeed. We are talking about more than $200m of taxpayers funds. This side of the Senate, for one, is not going to be party to legislating for that amount of money in total contradiction of, and with total disdain for, everything that has been built up by this Senate over many years, throughout its history, and of which we are, rightly, very proud on behalf of the people of Australia: namely, the need for proper parliamentary scrutiny of expenditure.I do not know what the attitude of the Democrats is on this matter. I hope that they will have listened very carefully to my remarks tonight, because a failure by this Senate to adopt this motion will set back the proper and legitimate processes of this Senate and of this Parliament on behalf of the people of Australia by many, many years. So I urge the Democrats to give very careful consideration to this proposal. I will listen with a very great interest to their response.

content: —I will be very brief because essentially I addressed Senator Bjelke-Petersens amendment in my second reading response and at this time of night I do not wish to duplicate my previous remarks.I thank Senator Short for the manner in which he presented his remarks. He may have thought I was not paying due attention, but I did hear them. While I did not agree, of course, with all his points, I did appreciate the manner in which they were presented and I thank him for that.I take the question of accountability extremely seriously, as does the Government. Even though I spend many hours of my life going through the process, sometimes in debate with Senator Short, I think it is a very important one. I believe the process we have is the best balance of the competing factors available to us. I feel that the points that have been raised by honourable senators are important and, wanting to provide the maximum amount of information possible, I sought advice on the situation with regard to the Advance to the Minister for Finance, should this Bill be referred to a committee.It was Senator Shorts understanding that at 30 March the balance on the AMF was $90m, which is broadly correct to the nearest million. It is assessed that at the end of March, with some anticipated requirements that have to be met, the balance would be $79m; the April anticipated requirements are $88m. So by the end of April—that is, if the Parliament fails to pass these Bills by the end of April, which is certain—the balance would be about minus $8m, with the anticipated requirements for May being $102m. So for each day in May that we fail to pass Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), have we not passed Appropriation Bill No. 5, we will be running further and further into deficit and we will more and more have to make extraordinary adjustments to meet contractual requirements, or we will fail to meet them or have to adjust them.They are important payments. Senator Kernot referred to the most socially important payments, but the others to which this Bill refers are also socially important payments. The child-care fee relief, because of the date of payment, et cetera, is most easily identifiable. Therefore it has tended to be the example that we have used in this debate. But I remind honourable senators that this Bill relates not only to child-care fee relief, but also to assistance for the aged and to labour market programs. So it is important that we recognise not only the accountability requirements, but also our responsibility to appropriate the money necessary to meet these socially important programs and enable the Government to meet its contractual obligations. content: —I move:That Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92 be referred to the Standing Committees on Community Affairs, Employment, Education and Training and Finance and Public Administration for consideration and report on or before Wednesday, 29 April 1992.The reasons for moving this motion are similar to those I outlined in respect of Senator Bjelke-Petersens amendment on which the Senate has just divided. The essential reason is that the Governments proposal completely stands on its head the procedure for the consideration and scrutiny of the expenditure of public moneys by the Senate and Parliament, which has been in place for many years.The Senate is being asked to pass Appropriation Bill (No. 5) in advance of consideration of its expenditure, totalling more than $204m, by an Estimates committee. Earlier in his remarks Senator McMullan referred to the item of child-care fee relief. He pointed out there was a need for a quarterly payment on 1 April, or very close thereafter. What he did not really explain was whether there are any alternatives to the unprecedented course of action being proposed here, which would enable that child-care fee relief to be paid.In addition, I believe I am correct in saying that he did not refer at all to the reasons for the apparent urgency of the appropriation of the other $140m which is the subject of this Bill, made up of $87m for labour market program assistance for job-seekers and industry, and $50m for residential care for older people. They are both very important programs. This debate is not about the importance of those programs; this debate is about the method of handling the consideration of the expenditure under these programs.Only one month ago the Government introduced legislation in the form of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) to appropriate money for all of these programs. Suddenly, over the last four weeks the Government has tried to have us believe that the circumstances in relation to those programs have changed so much that unprecedented action has to be taken, namely, the amendment of Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4, which are currently before the Senate, and the substitution of those amended Bills by Appropriation Bill (No. 5).Senator McMullan queried some of the comments made and suspicions raised by the Opposition as to whether or not there is a link in this process between this legislation and the $317m bribe being offered to electors in advance of the Wills by-election which is to be held in a couple of weeks time. Whether there is a conspiracy or not, the suspicion lingers. Certainly, what is indisputable is that the Government has failed monumentally in the normal correct financial management of its affairs and is asking the Senate to bail it out because of its incompetence. In so doing, the Government is asking the Senate to overturn procedures for the proper scrutiny of public moneys which have been built up over many years, and of which the Senate is rightfully proud on behalf of the people of Australia. That is a disgrace and should not be tolerated. (Time expired)

content: —I suppose the short answer to the question is no, but I will try to be a little more helpful. What we expect from Treasury when it brings down the Budget—not so much the Additional Estimates, although that to a lesser extent—is an explanation of the assumptions underlying the Estimates and the basis upon which the calculations have been made, so that we can challenge the assumptions and challenge the assessments. name: Senator OCHEE
content: —I rise this evening to put a number of happy facts before the Senate. This is a sequel to a matter I raised in this place on 5 March about a family of sugarcane farmers in Queensland who, as a result of drought and high interest rates, incurred farm losses and farm debt and the previously sorry situation in which that family found themselves in relation to their pension.The senior lady in the family had her age pension cut by 85 per cent because QIDC household assistance support was categorised as income by the Department of Social Security. As a result, there was a sense of frustration and humiliation over the inaction of the Department of Social Security in relation to those changes to the pension. It was referred to them by me as a case of Mr and Mrs N who are sugarcane farmers in the mid-north coast of Queensland in Mr Courtices electorate of Hinkler. The tale I have to tell is one from which every senator can take some heart.I understand that on 6 March or thereabouts, Mrs N received a telephone call from the regional Social Security office. I am very pleased to say that it was a kind, courteous and professional call about her pension. The upshot of the conversation was that her age pension had been reviewed and altered. Honourable senators may recall that on 10 October 1991, Mrs Ns pension was assessed at $131.60 a fortnight, but it will now be $273.30 a fortnight. What is more, she was credited for the arrears and given pension entitlements. I am led to believe that that telephone call lifted hopes, restored faith in mankind and, what is more, provided hope for the future.At this point, I seek leave to incorporate a copy of a letter from the Department of Social Security to Mrs N dated 19 March 1992. I regret that I have not had an opportunity to show it to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) beforehand, but it is good news rather than bad.Leave granted.The document read as follows—ABOUT YOUR PENSIONDear MrsI am writing to you about your pension payment.Due to a change in your circumstances your Age Pension has been reviewed and altered.You are also entitled to fringe benefits from 26 March 1992.Your fortnightly rate will be $273.30, starting on 26 March 1992. This is your pension entitlement, including any allowances you are entitled to. Your rate is based on your combined income. The $1,277.00 arrears we owe you will also be credited on 26 March 1992.Please read the back of this letter. It will tell you about your future payments, the income held, your Social Security rights and when you have to contact us.If you have any questions about your Social Security payments, please contact this office at the address and telephone number at the top of this letter. It will help if you have this letter with you.Yours sincerelyRegional Manager
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator OCHEE
content: —I thank the Minister. As I said, I am very pleased about the matter. More importantly, there is a handwritten note on the letter which says simply, `Thank You. The thank you is for the Senate. It is for those who heard and instituted the action to remedy the problem for a very genuine case. I also place on record my thanks to those who were responsible for this prompt and courteous action.Welfare in Australia is now a big business, unfortunately. Australia now has some five million people receiving social security payments and a work force of some 8.5 million people. This represents only one and a half workers for every welfare recipient. Those five million plus welfare recipients include: more than 9.1 million families receiving family allowance for nearly 3.7 million children; nearly 200,000 low income working families receiving the family allowance supplement; almost 1.4 million age pensioners; another 30,000 spouses and carers receiving payments; more than 815,000 people receiving Job Search allowance or Newstart allowance; more than 75,000 people temporarily too sick to work, which is an incredible number; carers receiving payments of child disability allowance for more than 45,000 children; and more than 30,000 people receiving special benefits because they are unable to support themselves temporarily but are not eligible for any other type of support.It is acknowledged that some of the recipients also work, but there is no denying the fact that, if welfare recipients wanted to form one united union or association, they certainly would be a force to be reckoned with. For example, imagine the fuss such a powerful lobby group would have made about the Department of Social Securitys mistake regarding the mailing out of 6,000 notices of confidential income and bank account details to the wrong people.Clearly, the computer in the Department of Social Security dictates what people should do, what questions they should ask and what they can and cannot do. Anything out of the ordinary falls in the too-hard basket at the DSS. I am just pleased to say that Mrs N, although she may have been a statistic in the mainframe in Canberra and although she may have fallen into the too-hard basket, is one case which was handled by hand, handled satisfactorily, and that is why the DSS response to Mrs Ns case was so much appreciated by me and her family.

name: Senator CHAMARETTE
content: —At Senator Walshs invitation during his speech on the resource security legislation, I wish to respond to his comments regarding my predecessors application for sickness pension. I wish to place my response on the public record to avoid wasting any further time in the normal course of speaking on particular issues.Firstly, I am not absolutely clear what Senator Walshs particular agenda is in this matter. If his concern is genuinely directed towards anyone perpetrating a fiscal scam, he should readdress his efforts to the due process of the Parliamentary Trust Committee whose task it is to ensure that everyone retiring receives their correct entitlements. My understanding is that the decision should be based on neutral principles which have already been laid down. Personal attacks and value judgments by Senator Walsh are as irrelevant to that process as my personal view that former Senator Vallentine deserves every bit of recognition she gains for the deep personal cost of her years of stressful parliamentary involvement.Secondly, I wish to remind the Senate of the following facts: it was suggested by the Deputy President of the Senate, Senator Colston, a member of the Parliamentary Trust, that ex-Senator Vallentine apply for a sickness pension following her decision to leave the Senate. Senator Colston approached ex-Senator Vallentine after hearing that ill health was one of her reasons for retiring.Former Senator Vallentines work as a senator was a major contributing factor to her ill health. Her problem was of intermittent migraine attacks which increased in severity over time and caused a loss of 48 days in the last year. Although she was lively and well in between these attacks, they were totally debilitating when they set in and, unfortunately, were not predictable in their occurrence. This matter is a complex one for the Parliamentary Trust as it has implications for all other sufferers of intermittent illnesses as opposed to life threatening or permanently debilitating illness.Nevertheless, ex-Senator Vallentine has expressed herself as being `quite relaxed about whatever the Parliamentary Trust decides about my eligibility for a pension. I, too, express confidence in the due process. I understand this matter will be considered by the Trust this week and I sincerely hope its decision will put an end to this matter.Question resolved in the affirmative.Senate adjourned at 10.39 p.m.

name: Senator Walsh
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 14 August 1991:(1) Do Aboriginal Legal Services in all States provide or offer to provide legal representation to all Aborigines who have been charged?(2) Is representation always provided to Aborigines who apply for it; if not, on what grounds is it refused?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Collins
content: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has been provided with the following information by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in response to the Honourable Senators question:(1) Aboriginal Legal Services are independent incorporated bodies and are funded to provide legal services for Aboriginal people in specific geographic locations. The extent to which those bodies provide legal/professional services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is determined by the priorities set, within available resources, by the Aboriginal Legal Services.(2) Aboriginal Legal Services have played a central role over the past 20 years in assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to obtain legal representation in criminal and civil litigation. They have been the primary means by which the right to representation in legal matters has been given effect in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.Aboriginal Legal Services are subject to the same professional ethical requirements as any other provider of legal services. The management and executive of legal services are free to determine whether a matter should be supported. Situations where an Aboriginal Legal Service may decline to accept a client would include cases which would involve a breach of professional ethical duty, a conflict of interest, or where an action would involve one Aboriginal person opposing another.While decisions to provide representation are a management prerogative, lack of funding is usually the operative factor in decisions to refuse to provide legal representation.
