name: Senator Newman
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans Affairs, upon notice, on 18 February 1992:How many war widow pensioners have been identified by the Department of Veterans Affairs as being financially disadvantaged as a result of restrictions on eligibility to some Department of Social Security pensions and the freezing of age pension.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Tate
content: —The Minister for Veterans Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:The exact number of war widows who are excluded from eligibility for a pension or allowance from the Department of Social Security is unknown. However, it is estimated that approximately 300 are affected by these eligibility restrictions.The Minister for Social Security has advised the honourable senator, in answer to a similar question, that at January 1992 there were some 44,100 war widows whose rate of Social Security pension was being paid at the rate payable prior to November 1986.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Tambling
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs:(1) Has the department considered the report The Concept Community in Aboriginal Policy and Service Delivery by the North Australia Development Unit of the Department of Social Security?(2) What has been the response made to the recommendations?(3) How has the department adapted to the recommendation in the report that `any statement of/ or review of policies or servicss for Aboriginal Australians must be preceded by: (a) clarification by each particular authority or its understanding of and use of the concept community (b) a statement of the evidence which that authority uses to conclusively support that Aboriginal towns, generally and in particular, are in fact communities in their defined terms; (c) a demonstration of how the defined characteristics of `community are linked in an integral way with the goals, objectives and strategies of the policy of service to be delivered; and (d) a demonstration of how the link between the definition of `community and the goals objectives etc provide the most effective service delivery while at the same time ensuring that the civil rights of the residents are guaranteed and equal access to services and facilities is enhanced.(4) Have any budget initiatives been associated with the recommendations?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Collins
content: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senators question:(1) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has a copy of the report The Concept Community in Aboriginal Policy and Service Delivery. It is being circulated throughout the Commission for consideration by officers developing policy and delivering services.(2) There has been no response to date to the recommendations.(3) These issues will be considered in association with an ATSIC response to the Report.(4) No.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Tambling
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Torres Strait Islander Affairs:(1) Has the department considered the report on Welfare Service Delivery: Options for Remote Areas by the North Australia Development Unit of the Department of Social Security.(2) What is the departments response to the finding that mobile services `are a viable response to the service needs of scattered regional populations.(3) Has the department conducted a `post implementation review and evaluation of the services in order to determine the strategies required in setting up and maintain such a service, and the effectiveness of those strategies?(4) What is the departments response to the suggestion in the report that the full potential mobile services is not being achieved due to the reluctance of Government to fund, staff and resource services so they can provide both a mobile and a multi-service facility to remote area residents.(5) Has the department given the report consideration in the context of other reports on welfare or social services delivery in remote Australia, for example, the report of Remote Rural Womens Access to Social Security, also by the North Australia Development Unit.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Collins
content: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senators question:(1) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has a copy of the report Welfare Service Delivery: options for remote areas. It is being circulated throughout the Commission for consideration by officers developing policy and delivering services.(2) A preliminary analysis of the report has shown its focus is broad in nature and does not deal with the special needs and aspirations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in terms of welfare service delivery. This may reduce its effectiveness and relevance for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.Nevertheless many of the issues addressed are relevant to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.(3) No.(4) The Commission is not in a position to provide a response to the suggestion until consideration of the report is completed.(5) The report is being considered in the context of other reports of other welfare and social services delivery in remote Australia, such as The Remote Rural Womens Access to Social Security and the ATSIC Access and Equity Report.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Tambling
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:(1) Has the department considered the report entitled Filipino Brides in Remote Areas by the North Australia Development Unit (Social Security).(2) What conclusions have been drawn from the report.(3) Has the department conducted any investigations in relation to existing information dissemination systems in the Philippines, to ensure accurate and realistic information is given to prospective Filipino brides.(4) What are the findings of any such investigations.(5) What policy initiatives does the department currently have in place to improve awareness of the existence of social security/welfare service(s), for immigrants, and particularly in remote communities.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Bolkus
content: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) Yes, the Department has considered the report and issues raised, including services in isolated areas, information dissemination overseas and in Australia, and research on male sponsors.(2) The report broadly raises issues already under consideration.(3 and 4) Because of the problems facing some Filipino women in Australia, the Department for a long time has concentrated on providing accurate information to them, through:individual counselling when an application is lodged at the Australian Embassy in Manila;group counselling held once a week incorporating a video on Australian-Filipino marriages;two migration officers allocated full time to processing spouse/fiance applications in Manila who are specially trained in cultural issues and migration counselling;Staff in Manila work closely with the Philippine Governments Commission for Filipinos Overseas (CFO) in providing information to and counselling for spouse/fiance applicants (and their sponsors where possible). The Department has also:funded and helped to organise two visits to Australia of CFO counsellors to improve the counselling offered by the CFO. A third visit has been approved in principle.worked closely with community and government advisory bodies to identify the needs, including the information needs, of Filipino women.commissioned a research study No Filipinos in Manila: A Study of Filipino Migrants in Australia which identified some problems to be addressed but also indicated that Filipino-Australian marriage breakdown is no greater than average.recently allocated $20,000 for a study of problems associated with serial sponsorship of women from overseas. There have been complaints that some men are sponsoring a succession of women then abusing and deserting them. Information problems will be considered by the study.(5) Grants-in-Aid totalling $373,523 have been given to 10 organisations in each State and Territory to employ welfare workers to assist individual Filipinos in difficulty.The Department is also co-operating with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on a trial of the Australian Country Information System, making information on welfare and community services more available to isolated people.

name: Senator Walsh
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:What sitting fees or other payments are made to each member of the Child Care Accreditation Committee headed by Ms Jane Singleton.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Tate
content: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:Members of the Interim National Accreditation Council (INAC) are each paid according to rates set by the Remuneration Tribunal, Category 2, for part-time holders of public office. Sitting fees of $194 per day are paid to all INAC members, except the four Commonwealth, State and Territory Government officers. In addition, all members receive travel allowance of $190 per overnight stay in capital cities except Sydney, where the rate is $230 per overnight stay. Members are also paid air fares, taxi costs and other out of pocket expenses eg, phone calls.Ms Jane Singleton was appointed Chairperson of the Interim Council following a selected tender process.Ms Singleton is paid $800 per day (based on the Australian Journalists Association National Freelance Rate for Senior PR consultant) for six days per month for a period of 12 months, with either party having the right to terminate the Agreement on 3 months notice in writing, for example, if the Interim Council completes its Terms of Reference in a shorter period. This payment incorporates the sitting fee stipulated by the Remuneration Tribunal for chairpersons classified as part-time holders of public office. In addition, it recognises the Chairpersons responsibility for the INAC Support Office staff, and for the following media and community relations tasks, which reflect the broad community consultations which will be required as part of INACs work and in which the Chairperson will be expected to play a major role. The Chairperson is expected to:play a pro-active role in involving the public and private sectors in the development of the accreditation system;promote a sense of ownership and participation by the child care industry in the accreditation process;assist in bringing together the differing interests within the child care industry and community in relation to the accreditation of child care services;act as spokesperson for the Interim Council and assist with the public promotion of its work;advance the case for accreditation with its objective of ensuring good quality child care; andmeet a very tight and demanding time schedule for the production of a number of reports and, finally, a national accreditation system, as required by the Councils Terms of Reference.Ms Singleton is also paid airfares, taxi costs, travel allowance at $190 per overnight stay in capital cities other than Sydney, which is where she resides, and other out of pocket expenses, eg, phone calls.

name: Senator Spindler
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:With reference to the Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales:(1) Was evidence given to the Commission that the Master Builders Association (MBA), with the knowledge of the NSW Building Services Corporation, diverted millions of dollars provided by both Commonwealth and NSW Governments for the express purpose of funding an MBA apprentice training scheme.(2) Was the MBA scheme initiated in 1977 as a `non-profit scheme.(3) Was evidence given to the Commission that the MBA scheme was, in fact, profitable for the MBA.(4) How much finance has the Commonwealth contributed to the MBA scheme, and other similar schemes around Australia, over the past 10 years.(5) During the past ten years were audit reports called for and MBA Annual Reports scrutinised before making further contributions to the MBA scheme.(6) Will steps be taken to recover any Commonwealth funds contributed to the MBA over the past 10 years.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Cook
content: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) The Minister understands that some evidence was given that the MBA scheme was generating large surpluses which were used for the general purposes of the MBA. However, since the Commonwealth had no financial interest in establishing the MBA scheme, nor in providing funds for its administration, there was no diversion of Commonwealth funds.(2) Whilst the scheme was promoted by the MBA as a non-profit scheme, the Commonwealth had no financial interest in the establishment of the MBA group training scheme and is not aware of its status at that time.(3) The Commonwealth understands that evidence was given to the Royal Commission that surplus funds, generated by the MBA scheme, were treated as profit by the MBA.(4) The Commonwealth Government provides a contribution towards the administrative costs of a number of group training schemes involved in the building industry. However, the NSW Master Builders Association Group Training Scheme has never been funded by the Commonwealth under these arrangements. With regard to other group schemes in the building industry, the Commonwealth contributed $2,830,492 towards administrative costs between 1987-88 and 1990-91. To establish the amount of Commonwealth contributions to these other schemes prior to 1987-88 would be a protracted exercise.Group schemes, as with other common law employers of indentured apprentices and trainees are eligible for and receive employer incentives under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training (CRAFT) and the Australian Traineeship System (ATS) at current rates. This includes rebates of training costs, available under CRAFT, for group training schemes approved to provide off-the-job training courses.(5) Since the Commonwealth has not provided any contributions to the establishment costs or administration of the MBA group training scheme, it has not called for audit reports.(6) No, such action is not required.
